Focus: Banks, Services, Commerce, Industry, Tourism, Tax Consultancy, Public Health Management
Annotation:
At the sites in Kiel, Lübeck and Flensburg, the DHSH offers the dual and practice-combined Bachelor degree course in Business Administration. Here students learn how companies are managed. The DHSH teaches the basics in a practice-oriented manner, so that the knowledge can be applied directly in the cooperating company during the practical period.
A large network of cooperation companies in Schleswig-Holstein and beyond have been working together for more than 40 years,. All information can be found at www.dhsh.de/partnerfirmen. The selection of industry focuses taught in the first four semesters is as diverse as the partner companies: Service management, trade management, industrial management, bank management, tourism management, logistics management, healthcare management or tax consultancy and advice.
Admission requirements: Completed study and training contract with a cooperation company of the DHSH
Area of study: Business Administration / Financial Management, Insurance / Accounting, Taxation, Controlling / Hotel, Catering, Tourism / Economic Sciences, Economics

Annotation:
The Duale Hochschule Schleswig-Holstein (DHSH) is a state-approved university of applied sciences under the auspices of the Wirtschaftsakademie Schleswig-Holstein and is the further development of the previous Berufsakademie (university of cooperative education). At the location in Kiel, the DHSH offers the dual and practice-oriented bachelor programs Business Computer Science (Bachelor of Science). Dual means: During the three-year course, the theory phases alternate with the DHSH and with the practical phases in a company.
A large network of cooperation companies in Schleswig-Holstein and beyond have been working together for more than 40 years,. All information can be found at www.dhsh.de/partnerfirmen.
Admission requirements: Completed study and training contract with a cooperation company of the DHSH

Target group: The career-integrated master's degree Digital Business & Innovation can be considered a stepping stone for careers in the digital age. The course content prepares students specifically for management positions in business development, strategy and strategic innovation. The master’s degree opens up a wide range of opportunities in a dynamic subject area with a promising future.
Admission requirements:
Proof of language skills: 
- Confirmation of the passed examination of an English module at the DHSH or at another university 
- or an internationally recognised B2 level certificate (not older than two years) or higher (e.g. Cambridge ESOL qualification)

Target group:
The consecutive degree course is designed for graduates of Economics courses, but also for other subjects, such as Political and Cultural Studies or Philosophy.
The studies are arranged in blocked lessons. As a result, students do not have to live and work near the course location.
Annotation:
All the major crises of recent years show: Economics fails to predict the future. But what if that's not even the real problem? When in turbulent times the actually important shaping forces do not focus on predictability and calculability, but on enabling and shaping an inherently uncertain future? 
In the degree course Economy - Imagination - Shaping the Future, the focus is on these problems and their solutions. For example, you can explore with us how imagination, public spirit, narratives and images of the future enable groundbreaking economic transformation processes.  We also work out how understandings of creative present and open future can renew economics from the ground up.
Admission requirements:
The Cusanus University for Social Design selects its students in personal selection interviews. What is decisive is your interest in the subject and in interdisciplinary and critical thinking, the enthusiasm for your own questions and your social commitment.
The formal requirements for admission are a relevant Bachelor's degree with at least 180 ECTS (or a comparable degree) and knowledge of Economics (preferably at least 30 ECTS).

Target group:
The consecutive degree course is designed for graduates of Economics courses, but also for other subjects, such as Political and Cultural Studies or Social Work.
The studies are arranged in blocked lessons. As a result, students do not have to live and work near the course location.
Annotation: Our new Master's degree Economy - Responsibility - Institutional Design will enable you to create a life-serving economy with a sense of community. In its educational formats, which are unique in Germany, you solve real problems of value-oriented management together with practitioners. In this way, you will try out a new and sustainable economic way of thinking that can prove itself directly in practice. We also develop with you an interdisciplinary understanding of today's human problems and show ways to overcome the economization of society and nature. Study, commitment and assumption of responsibility thus combine to form a meaningful whole!
Admission requirements:
The Cusanus University for Social Design selects its students in personal selection interviews. What is decisive is your interest in the subject and in interdisciplinary and critical thinking, the enthusiasm for your own questions and your social commitment.
The formal requirements for admission are a relevant Bachelor's degree with at least 180 ECTS (or a comparable degree) and knowledge of Economics (preferably at least 30 ECTS).

_University Name: SRH Berlin University of Applied Sciences
Target group:
The consecutive degree course is designed for graduates of Economics courses, but also for other subjects, such as Political and Cultural Studies or Social Work.

Annotation: Today, business and society are closely intertwined. How can a sustainable transformation of both succeed? How can the economy be rethought and redesigned? Our degree Economy - Sustainability - Shaping Society enables you to deal with such questions. Teaching and learning are transdisciplinary, combining theoretical and practical knowledge. In addition, you will study with us on a broad interdisciplinary foundation that innovatively combines plural economics, other social sciences and philosophy. You can study sustainability with us!
Admission requirements:
The Cusanus University for Social Design selects its students in personal selection interviews. What is decisive is your interest in the subject and in interdisciplinary and critical thinking, the enthusiasm for your own questions and your social commitment.
The formal requirements for admission are a relevant Bachelor's degree with at least 180 ECTS (or a comparable degree) and knowledge of Economics (preferably at least 30 ECTS).

Course Name: African Verbal and Visual Arts: Languages, Literatures, Media and Art (BA)
Annotation:
In this bachelor's degree course you will deal with the central crises of our time and the diverse approaches to a socio-ecological transformation of society. Our focus is economic thinking and acting. The degree course enables you to assume responsibility in a science-based and ethically reflective manner. To this end, you will develop a practice-oriented and philosophically sound interdisciplinary theoretical foundation. In the exchange of practice and research, you will develop new sustainable forms of economy. Study sustainability now! 
The studies are arranged in blocked lessons. As a result, students do not have to live and work near the course location.
Admission requirements: The general higher education entrance qualification or the intermediate school leaving certificate and completed professional training with relevant professional experience generally qualify you to apply for our accredited degree course. We assume that you want to shape the economy socially and ecologically in a responsible position. Voluntary work is part of our student profile and is actively encouraged by us.

Admission requirements:
Admission requires a first degree (at least a Bachelor's or comparable degree). In addition, proof of at least 142 LP in the subject Art (not including the final thesis), 20 LP in Educational Sciences (including a one-month orientation internship and at least a four-week internship in the professional field) and a final thesis of at least 12 LP must be submitted. 
In addition, proof of knowledge of 2 foreign languages must also be demonstrated, generally with a qualification for admission to higher education.

Course Name: Bachelor of Arts in International Relations: Politics and History
Focus: Cyber Physical Systems, Application Development, IT Management, Applied IT Security
Annotation:
The teaching content is taught through lectures, exercises, internships and projects. The hallmarks of the events are small groups, a seminar style and individual support. The course contents include the basics of Computer Science and Information Technology, Mathematics, Computer Engineering and Software Engineering. Further fields of specialisation are Applications of Computer Engineering in the field of Industry 4.0 (Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things and Services), Application Development, IT Management and IT Security.
The course aims are a secure mastery of the basics of Computer Science and Information Technology, independent solving of tasks in the technical environment through the use of computer and software systems, acquisition of key qualifications for professional life.
Admission requirements: according to the matriculation regulations

Course Name: Bachelor of Engineering in Biomedical Engineering
Focus: Support for the Elderly and Disabled, Child, Youth and Family Support, Health and Social Work, District and Community Development, Fundraising, Social Law, Methods in Social Work, Personnel Management, Ethics
Annotation:
36- or 48-month option possible.
Test the course for 4 weeks for free!
Admission requirements:
Study at the APOLLON University – even without a university entry qualification!
Access path 1: University entrance qualification according to § 33 Abs. 3-4 BremHG
For example, you have
- Abitur (general higher-education entrance qualification)
- Entrance qualification for studies at universities of applied sciences
- Subject-related higher education entrance qualification (if appropriate)
- Master craftsman's examination, business economist, advanced training or comparable qualification
- a university degree
- Equivalent foreign university entrance qualification (examination of recognition may be necessary)
With this prerequisite, you can immediately register for degrees at APOLLON University.
Access path 2: University entrance qualification according to § 33 Abs. 5 BremHG
You have completed at least 2 years of vocational training and at least 3 years of professional experience and participation in further training courses.
Then you can take the placement exam. This does not precede your courses, it takes place within the first 6 months of your courses. For this you must pass two examinations before the end of the first six months of study, which are part of the study plan anyway. We will send you all the necessary documents with your first course package.

_University Name: EBS University of Business and Law
Focus: Nursing, Mental Health, Psychiatry, Professional Decision-making, Psychiatric Interventions, Psychiatric Care System, Psychiatric Concepts, Case Management
Annotation:
Teaching of expert knowledge regarding care provision in various operational fields and enabling professional decision-making in cases involving complex details. Extended care practice is provided by drawing upon academic findings and clinical competences with the goal of undertaking diagnostic investigations and therapeutic interventions.
# You work as an academically trained skilled employee on a freelance, scientific basis with people who are mentally ill or impaired.
# As case manager or Primary Carer (PC) you operate in various settings and with varying operational emphases, whilst also coordinating the work of other primary and voluntary personnel. You operate as an equal partner within the treatment process.
Admission requirements:
You need to supply proof of: having been trained as a nurse, paediatric nurse, geriatric nurse, orthopedagogic nurse, physiotherapist
and we recommend at least two years professional experience in the field of psychiatrics
Area of study: Health Science / Nursing Science

_University Name: Technische Hochschule Nurnberg Georg Simon Ohm
Focus: Law and Administration, Methods and Methodical Action, Theology and Ethics, Theories and History, Interdisciplinary, Sociological and System-Theoretical Approaches, Can be selected individually: Management, Counselling, Protestant Social Work or Special Needs Education, Case Management
Admission requirements:
If you obtained the entrance qualification for universities of applied sciences or universities, you must proof of the following: 
- Completed vocational training or at least a three-year professional activity
- Current professional or voluntary activity, averaging at least 8 hours per week in the social sector.
If you have NOT obtained the entrance qualification for universities of applied sciences or universities, you must proof of the following:
- Successful completion of a state regulated advancement training or technically equivalent vocational training of at least two years with three years of professional activity in the occupation trained for or other vocational training and the successful passing of an entrance examination.
- Current professional or voluntary activity, averaging at least 8 hours per week in the social sector

Focus: a) Participation Management and Participation Advice, b) Case Management, c) Curative Education Diagnostics and ICF, d) Design of inclusive educational processes, e) International Concepts, f) Social Law, g) Ethics, h) Neurophysiological and Medical Basics, i) Systematic Consultancy and Mentoring, j) Operational Management, Personnel Management and Business Administration
Annotation: The next programme begins on 01 April 2020.
Admission requirements: Completed professional training as an educator in special education studies or in exceptional cases a completed professional training as a medical education nurse or educator or the study of related degree courses plus five years of professional experience in the field of special education studies plus two qualified courses of continuing education.

_University Name: Hochschule Wismar - University of Applied Sciences, Technology, Business and Design
Focus: Communication and Media Psychology, Psychological Empowerment
Annotation:
Distance learning with actual attendance classes (3 days/semester) at study centres in Hamburg, Munich or Magdeburg (MEU). The other classes are virtual and offered via the online campus.
If the number of students is sufficient, then always in the winter semester (October) and summer semester (April).
Admission requirements:
- Allgemeine Hochschulreife,
- Fachhochschulreife,
- bestandene Meisterprüfung,
  mittlerer Schulabschluss (mind. Realschulabschluss) und Qualifizierter Abschluss einer mind. 3-jährigen anerkannten Berufsausbildung, die eine 
  Durchschnitts-/Gesamt- oder Abschlussnote von 2,5 oder besser ausweist (sind diese Noten nicht ausgewiesen, gilt das arithmetische Mittel der 
  einzelnen Fachnoten),
- Abschluss einer beruflichen Aufstiegsfortbildung von mindestens 400 Unterrichtsstunden, einer Fachschule oder einer Berufs- oder 
  Verwaltungsakademie *
-  Abschlussprüfung in einem staatlich anerkannten und fachverwandten Ausbildungsberuf mit anschließender mindestens 2-jähriger 
   einschlägiger Berufstätigkeit und Bestehen einer gesonderten Hochschulzugangsprüfung *
  * gemäß Verordnung über den Zugang beruflich Qualifizierter zu den Hochschulen im Lande Hessen
Area of study: Developmental Psychology / Therapies, Miscellaneous

Course Name: German as a Foreign and Second Language
Annotation:
Distance learning with real presence phases and on-site examinations
Courses can be attended and exams taken at the following study centres: Kassel, Leipzig and Munich
Distance learning with virtual presence phases and on-site examinations
In this study variant, the courses are attended online in the virtual classroom. Exams can be taken at the following centres: Aalen, Baden-Baden, Berlin, Bochum, Bonn, Dresden, Friedrichshafen, Hamburg, Hanover, Heilbronn, Hoyerswerda, Kassel, Leipzig, Mannheim, Munich, Prichsenstadt, Regenstauf, Rinteln, Schwentinental / Kiel
Admission requirements:
- Abgeschlossenes Bachelor-Studium Wirtschaftspsychologie (B.Sc.) oder Medizinalfachberufe (B.A.)an der DIPLOMA Hochschule mit der 
  Abschlussnote von mindestens „befriedigend“
-  Einen mindestens mit "befriedigend" bestandenen Bachelorabschluss oder ein entsprechendes Diplom in einem Studiengang in Psychologie, 
   Angewandte Psychologie, Wirtschaft, Wirtschaftsingenieurwesen und Wirtschaftsinformatik oder in einer vergleichbaren Fachrichtung im 
   Umfang von wenigstens 180 ECTS (Credit Points).
-  Einen mindestens zum Bachelor oder Diplom gleichwertigen ausländischen Abschluss mit wenigstens "befriedigend" in einem geeigneten 
   Studiengang im Umfang von mindestens sechs Semestern/180 ECTS erreicht haben.
-  Qualifizierte Englisch-Kenntnisse auf B2-Niveau (Nachweis durch entsprechende Zertifikate z.B. TOEIC, TOEFL, Cambridge Certificate o.Ä. oder 
   durch ein Eignungsgespräch mit einem Vertreter/ einer Vertreterin der Hochschule, der/die fremdsprachlichen Kompetenzen beurteilt.)

only exams can be taken in Bochum (TA)
Admission requirements:
The previous vocational qualification must have been completed with a minimum grade of 2.5. Applicants with a lower grade must demonstrate their aptitude for a Master's degree programme in a placement interview with the Selection Committee.
Applicants from subject-related degree programmes such as Fine Arts, Architecture, etc. are subject to a separate procedure.

Focus: International Accounting and Financial Management, Classic and agile communication, leadership at a distance and mobile team skills, Contexts of Management Action in Digital Economies, Digital Business Management, Management of Information Systems and Digital Engineering, Digital Human Resources and Organisation Management, Digitisation and Enterprise Value
Target group: The course aims at graduates of business administration or related courses of study such as security management, industrial engineering or business informatics who would like to continue their education while working.
Annotation:
The Master Distance Learning programme Digital Management (i.V.) is conducted as an online programme with live online seminars on Saturdays (in individual cases, the events can also be scheduled in the evenings during the week). 
Participation in the events takes place via an online seminar room in our Online Campus via audio/video transmission.
Admission requirements:
Successfully completed Bachelor's or Diplom examination at DIPLOMA Hochschule or at another university or university of applied sciences (in particular in the fields of Economics or Law) or a degree from a foreign institution that is at least equivalent in the same or a related subject area with a standard period of study of at least 6 semesters.
Applicants with a final grade in their first professionally qualifying degree of 'adequate' may not participate in the Master's degree course. Applicants with the final grade of 'satisfactory' must demonstrate that they are able to successfully complete this course by means of a grading interview.
Area of study: Media Management / Human Resource Management / Economic Sciences, Economics

Focus: Business Administration, General Management, International Management
Target group: Graduates of a Bachelor's degree or Diplom in business administration or economics or university studies in a degree course that is closely related to one of these degrees.
Admission requirements:
Authorisation restriction: restricted admission:
Prerequisite for starting the course is proof of completion of a Diploma or Bachelor's degree in Business Administration or Economics or a study program, which has a substantial contextual proximity to one of these courses, either at a university or the conclusion of a corresponding accredited Bachelor's program at a vocational university with an overall grade of at least good (2.5).
Academic programs are considered to be close to one another, when their curriculum includes study and examination achievements in the fields of Business Administration or Economics totalling at least 75% of the total volume. Furthermore, according to sentence 1, the courses must include at least 6 semesters or 180 credit points according to the European Credit Transfer and Accumulation System (ECTS). Whether the prerequisites are met or not is decided upon by a commission elected by the faculty council. The commission consists of three members, chosen from among academic staff, and professors in the Master's programs Business Administration (four-semester) and Financial Management (four-semester). At least two members must be professors.

Focus: General Management, International Management, Business Administration
Target group: Graduates of a Diplom or Bachelor's degree in Business Administration or Economics or a degree course with significant content that is close to one of these courses.
Admission requirements:
Admission restriction: restricted
qualification: The completion of a Diploma or Bachelor's course in Business Administration, Economics or a subject-related study program at a university or university of applied sciences or the completion of a corresponding accredited Bachelor's program at a vocational university with an overall grade of at least good (2.5).
Registration requirement: Academic programs are considered to be close to one another, when their curriculum includes study and examination achievements in the fields of Business Administration or Economics totalling at least 60% of the total volume. In addition, the programs must include at least 210 credit points according to the European Credit Transfer and Accumulation System (ECTS). If the courses cover only 180 points after the ECTS, the applicants can obtain the remaining 30 credits by successfully completing an internship lasting at least 20 weeks or 750 hours (can be carried out in a maximum of two part-internships) according to the Practice Regulations of the Department of Economics. The regulation of the completion of an internship to receive the missing 30 credits refers exclusively to the application for the summer semester 2016!
Admission to the course: The program starts annually from the summer semester. Applications are possible online from the end of November of each year until the application deadline 15.01. The allocation of study places is carried out by the Fachhochschule Dortmund.

Course Name: European Legal Practice LLM Joint Degree
Focus: Accounting & Controlling, Finance, Risk and Insurance
Target group: Graduates of a Bachelor's degree or Diplom in business administration or economics or university studies in a degree course that is closely related to one of these degrees.
Annotation: This degree course is also offered with a standard period of 3 semesters.
Admission requirements:
Prerequisite for starting the course is proof of completion of a Diploma or Bachelor's degree in Business Administration or Economics or a study program, which has a substantial contextual proximity to one of these courses, either at a university or the conclusion of a corresponding accredited Bachelor's program at a vocational university with an overall grade of at least good (2.5).
Academic programs are considered to be close to one another, when their curriculum includes study and examination achievements in the fields of Business Administration or Economics totalling at least 75% of the total volume. Furthermore, according to sentence 1, the courses must include at least 6 semesters or 180 credit points according to the European Credit Transfer and Accumulation System (ECTS). Whether the prerequisites are met or not is decided upon by a commission elected by the faculty council. The commission consists of three members, chosen from among academic staff, and professors in the Master's programs Business Administration (four-semester) and Financial Management (four-semester). At least two members must be professors.

(1) The prerequisite for admission to the Master's degree program is the completion of a Bachelor of Science or Bachelor of Engineering degree or a Chartered Engineer degree at a University of Applied Sciences or a corresponding accredited Bachelor's degree program at a vocational university with an overall grade of at least good ( 2.5)
a)

of Telecommunications Technology or

Admission requirements:
(1)\tAdmission requirements are
1.a)\tCompleted Diplom or Bachelor's degree in photography/photographic design or a comparable design-related course including curricular components of a specialisation in photography from a university of applied sciences, university of art or institution of higher education or a corresponding accredited Bachelor's degree course from a university of cooperative education with a final grade of at least good (2.3 or better) or 
1.b)\t completed academic studies in communication design or a comparable course related to design or a Bachelor's or Diplom degree in arts and humanities, media or cultural studies from a university of applied sciences or art school or university or a corresponding accredited Bachelor's degree course from a university of cooperative education or subjects that are explicitly related to practical photography and photographic research with a final grade of at least good (2.3 or better) and a Diplom or Bachelor's thesis on a practical or theoretical topic from the field of photography.
Foreign degree courses in accordance with number 1.a) and 1.b) must also require a thesis (Diplom or Bachelor's thesis) equivalent to the minimum requirements of degree courses at German universities.
2.) A committee set up by the department council and elected by the department of design for a four year term consisting of the course degree head of the Master's in Photography Photographic Studies, two other full-time lecturers, one of whom is a professor, determines whether the study requirements in paragraph 1 section 1 numbers 1.a) and 1.b) have been fulfilled.
Applicants must present the documents needed to demonstrate the fulfilment of study requirements in accordance with paragraph 1 section 1 number 1.a) and 1.b)\; if required, the committee may request additional documents. The committee meets and passes resolutions in a closed session. It is capable of passing a resolution when at least two members are present. The applicant will receive written notice of the committee's decision. Letters of refusal must include advice on applicable legal remedies. 
(2)\tProof of course-related artistic-creative aptitude.
Aptitude in art and design is determined upon request based on the assessment of work samples submitted by the applicant. The assessment is carried out by a committee set up by the department council of the Department of Design in a special procedure. Further details are governed by the regulations for determining aptitude in art and design for the Master's in Photography Photographic Studies at the Dortmund University of Applied Sciences and Arts.

Area of study: Art (Teaching Degree) / Educational Sciences

Target group:
The Master's course is aimed at graduates in Economics or a related subject.
Recent observations clearly underline the need of high-quality education, combining analytical skills in financial risk management with professional knowledge in internal and external accounting. Therefore, this Master program rests on two pillars, Accounting and Finance, featuring an integrated analytical approach to graduate education in these fields.
The M. Sc. in Accounting and Finance is designed as a 3-semester program, taught according to the European Credit Transfer System. Successful completion requires students to achieve a total of 90 ECTS credits. The curriculum includes both courses in Accounting and Finance. Compulsory courses are designed to teach important foundations, while field courses allow students to specialize according to their individual interests and abilities. Some of the courses are taught in English. Successful completion of the program also requires a master thesis (24 ECTS credits), written in the third and final term.
Admission requirements: Earlier application deadline of 15 May.

Target group:
The focus of the Adult Education/Continuing Education programme is on the research-based examination of processes, forms and structures of adult lifelong learning.
The Master’s degree in Adult Education/Continuing Education leads to a professional qualification at a high academic level. This paves the way for challenging and sophisticated, academically sound work in all areas of the postgraduate education and social system.
The concept of the course is aimed at the ability to perform research-based development work that contributes to the professional quality of education and lifelong learning. Such an approach serves future specialists to assess and further develop the empirical, theoretical and pragmatic foundations of their professional activities, on the basis of relevant academic discourses and procedures.
The overall orientation of the MA course in Adult Education/Continuing Education is highly practical and provides the skills necessary for an independent, in-depth academic examination of:
• Issues in education,
• issues of learning and teaching of adults,
• issues in counselling adults, 
• issues in the planning and organisation of learning and development processes, and
• issues regarding the evaluation of processes, facilities and systems.
Admission requirements: Earlier application deadline on 15 June

Target group:
The wide variety of courses in this Masters program ranges from those on Americas colonial past and early literary culture to those covering contemporary themes in race, class, gender, religious, ethnic, and regional studies.
We pride ourselves on offering students an interdisciplinary curriculum which emphasizes student autonomy, and academic collaboration and exchange.
The program consists of four core aspects:
American Literature and Culture
- Interdisciplinary Profile
- Research
- Practice
Within this structure, students are exposed to the fundamental theoretical framework of American Studies while completing collaborative and independent research projects.
Each year, our department welcomes a number of esteemed guest professors from international universities. Teaching lectures and seminars, our guests bring new and innovative research and perspectives to students of American Studies.
All students of American Studies are encouraged to spend time in an English-speaking country. This is an invaluable opportunity for students to work with experienced professionals in a different academic environment.
Admission requirements: Earlier application deadline of 31 May.
Area of study: American Studies / Media Studies / General Linguistic Science

Annotation: For more information on course contents and course organisation, see our course flyer:
Area of study: Ancient Oriental Studies / Oriental Studies

Target group:
The Department of Ancient Near Eastern Philology at the Institute for the Cultures of the Ancient Near East (IANES) at the University of Tübingen emerged from the Ancient Near Eastern seminar and is one of the most renowned institutions of its kind both in Germany and abroad. The range of courses covers the entire spectrum of ancient Near Eastern Philology, both in terms of language and cultural history. Research focuses on the literature and history of Mesopotamia from the 3rd millennium to the 1st millennium BC.
Ancient Near Eastern Philology deals with the languages and writings of ancient Mesopotamia (modern day: Iraq) and the neighbouring areas of Anatolia, Syria and Iran, which are characterised by highly developed, multicultural societies at the beginning of history. The period covered extends from the first written records around 3000 BC. until the 3rd century AD. The focus is on the Akkadian (Babylonian-Assyrian) as the oldest documented Semitic language and the Sumerian. Both languages (including Hittite, Elamite, Ugaritic) were written in cuneiform, which was the most important writing system in the Middle East for over three millennia.
Area of study: Ancient Oriental Studies / Media Studies / General Linguistic Science

Target group:
This area of study delves into the rich tradition of English literature in Great Britain, as well as the newer literatures that have emerged in English across the globe. Of particular interest is the role literature has played across a range of cultural contexts throughout history, both in terms of its functions and achievements.
Literature is therefore viewed as an integral part of the culture of the modern era, in the widest sense of the phrase encompassing cultural developments from the Middle Ages to the post-modern era. More recent developments in the field, built on the concept of literary studies as a form of media studies and cultural studies, form the basis for exploring the relationship between literary texts and other types of text and media, thus creating a productive link between literary and cultural studies. The ability to critically analyse and reflect on texts of any kind constitutes the core principle underlying teaching and learning in this area.
A Masters degree in English Studies will prepare students for jobs predominantly (but not exclusively) in the areas of public relations, adult education, intercultural communication, and in similar career fields where a strong background in communicative and intercultural skills, in addition to excellent foreign language skills, plays a crucial role.
Admission requirements: Earlier application deadline of 31 May.

Target group:
The M.Sc. program 'Applied & Environmental Geoscience' (AEG) is an international research-oriented study program focusing on the evaluation and solution of environmental problems. Special emphasis is given to environmental problems in the subsurface such as the pollution of drinking water supplies from groundwater resources, the non-sustainable use of natural resources, the impact of short and long term waste disposal, the impact of climate and land-use change on soil and water quality.
The program aims for a comprehensive understanding of the physical, chemical, and biological process mechanisms in the geo- and hydrosphere. Students from various science backgrounds learn to qualitatively and quantitatively address complex processes in soils, water and air and to evaluate environmental risks based on multi-disciplinary approaches.
Annotation: Application deadline for foreign applicants is 31 March.
Admission requirements:
Bachelor of Science in Geology, Geoecology, Geography, Physics, Chemistry, Engineering, Mathematics or Biology\; English proficiency (TOEFL passed with at least 79 points ibt). 
Application deadline for international applicants is 31 March.
Area of study: Geosciences / Environmental Science

Target group:
The M.Sc. in Natural Science Archaeology is a two-year, research-oriented course that deals with the wide range of scientific applications for addressing archaeological and historical questions.
In the first semester, students will get an overview of the different disciplines of natural science archaeology and then specialise in one of these disciplines. The course is not focused on specific periods or regions, but focuses on methods and topics.
Facilities
• Laboratory for old DNA
• Laboratory for organic petrology and micromorphology
• Sedimentological and soil-science laboratory
• Palaeoanthropology Imaging Lab
• Palaeoanthropology High Resolution Computer Tomography Laboratory
• Radiocarbon and luminescence dating (Curt-Engelhorn Centre Archaeometry Mannheim)
• Archaeobotanical laboratory
• Large comparative collections of human osteology, fauna and botany (seeds, fruits and charcoal)
• Analytical laboratory and isotope geochemistry (Curt-Engelhorn Centre Archaeometry Mannheim)
• Measuring room for trace element and isotope analysis (Curt-Engelhorn Centre Archaeometry Mannheim)
• X-ray fluorescence analysis (Curt-Engelhorn Centre Archaeometry Mannheim)
Although the Institute for Natural Science Archaeology was officially founded only in 2007, this area already has a long and excellent tradition at the University of Tübingen. As early as 1896, Ernst Koken taught human evolution and prehistory at the Faculty of Mathematics and Natural Sciences. Since then, numerous courses in Natural Science Archaeology have been taught in Tübingen. For many decades Tübingen was the only German university with an archaeology department within a faculty of natural sciences. Over the past decades, Natural Science Archaeology in Tübingen has been closely linked to the Chair of Early Prehistory and Quaternary Ecology and that of Bioarchaeology. In recent years, a chair for archaeometry and two new junior professorships have been set up at the Institute of Natural Science Archaeology. The institute is divided into six pillars: archaeometry, archaeobotany, geoarchaeology, palaeoanthropology, palaeogenetics and zoo archaeology.
Area of study: Anthropobiology / Archaeology

Target group: The prehistory, early history and archaeology of the Middle Ages deal with the legacies of man from past times. These are developed using archaeological methods in order to scientifically evaluate and interpret them. The time frame here extends from the beginnings of mankind through the Stone and Metal Ages to the Middle Ages and modern times. The geographical range includes primarily the Old World. Depending on the research direction, it ranges from Central Europe to the Mediterranean region and Africa to Asia.

Art History in Tübingen represents in research and teaching the entire bandwidth of the subject, from the Late Antiquity to the present.
The spectrum ranges from the visual arts through architecture and applied arts to photography, film, electronically generated media and genre-defying artistic processes.
The Tübingen Master’s in Art History is characterised by its media-historical breadth and practical relevance, which is defined by the institute's graphic collection and the large art collections of the region.
The Master’s programme also benefits from the interdisciplinary range of courses at the University of Tübingen.
Studying in the “Alte Burse”, the oldest university building in the middle of the old town of Tübingen on the banks of the river Neckar. Founded in 1894, the institute has a graphic collection, an extensive library with over 50,000 volumes, is equipped to the latest technical standards and has its own image database. 
A broad-based and up-to-date teaching programme, attractive secondary courses and the high density of museums, exhibition halls and art monuments in the region make Tübingen an ideal location for studying art history.

Target group:
The focus of the Master’s programme in Astro and Particle Physics is on a distinct quantitative approach as is usual in physics, along with the acquisition of essential practical skills (primarily in the lab) with respect to problem sets in the field of Astro and Particle Physics.
The Master’s in Astro and Particle Physics is an international research-oriented two-year programme established by the Kepler-Center. This programme connects science from the fields of particle physics, astrophysics and cosmology and combines different disciplines in experimental and theoretical physics, astronomy and astrophysics. The education will be in English throughout, which prepares the students for the increasing internationalisation in industry and modern society.
Area of study: Astronomy / Physics

Focus: Biochemistry, Molecular Biology, Cell Biology, Chemical Biology, Molecular Medicine, Biophysics
Target group:
The 2-year degree in English will provide you with knowledge of the very latest developments in biochemical, molecular and cellular biology as well as with cutting edge laboratory and bioinformatics skills. 
What sets this program apart is its broad approach. It offers you an in-depth look at many aspects of molecular life science without early specialization, while allowing you to dig deeper in areas of your choice. Topics range from biochemical, structural, cellular and molecular biology to neuroscience, cell signalling, plant physiology as well as cancer biology.
The course is highly modular and adaptable to your personal preferences. Few elements of the degree are fixed and there is a wealth of options. You will be given the opportunity to work in several different labs to hone your skills and develop your preferences.
The master is organized by the Interfaculty Institute of Biochemistry (IFIB) which is a tight-knit community of a dozen research groups. Like the degree, the local labs cover a broad range of research topics from structural biochemistry to model organisms. On top of the in-house expertise, several excellent research institutions working in the fields of developmental biology, biocybernetics and neuroscience are located in the immediate vicinity.
Admission requirements: The application deadline differs here and is 31 May for the winter term and 15 January for the summer term!
Area of study: Biochemistry / Chemistry

Area of study: Bioinformatics / Medical Informatics

Target group:
The MSc course in Bioinformatics consists of lectures on bioinformatics, computer science and life sciences. The main goal of the course is to enable students to successfully deal with biological questions through high-throughput technologies and bioinformatic methods in the interdisciplinary team. Efficient and modern methods for the analysis, visualisation and storage of mass data are taught. In doing so, emphasis is placed on practical relevance and research. The broad field of topics in Tübingen includes, among other things, genomics and transcriptomics, protein and drug development, microbiota analysis and systems biology.
There are three variants of the course, tailored to different groups of applicants: Variant (A) for students with a Bachelor’s in bioinformatics, variant (B) for biologists and other life scientists, variant (C) for computer scientists. Most classes are in English; in the variant (A) it is possible to study exclusively in English.
Computer Science in Tübingen is one of the most research-intensive in Germany and is internationally known. It maintains close partnerships with major business enterprises and research institutes (e.g. three Max Planck Institutes in Tübingen) at the national and international levels. It is distinguished by the interdisciplinary cooperation with medicine, biology, psychology, media science and many other disciplines at the University of Tübingen.

The inter-professional and interdisciplinary Masters Degree program in Biomedical Technologies offers practical orientation and internationality.
The Master’s program at the University of Tübingen is an excellent choice for students seeking advanced academic and application-oriented research training in emerging fields of Biomedical Technologies, integrating the core areas of implantology, bioimaging, and nanoanalytics/interfaces. The training is offered by experts in basic as well as clinical sciences and provides a comprehensive overview of the area.
The program provides lectures and modules embedded in a modern technological and medical environment and supported by an interdisciplinary team of internationally recognized scientists.
-excellent study conditions in small training groups with individual contact to researchers and clinicians.
-close cooperation with more than 40 universities all over the world, providing the option to pursue practical work experience or to write the Master s thesis outside Germany.
-close interaction with companies and research institutes in Medical Technologies and Biomedical Technologies to ensure a competence based study program, opportunities for practical experiences, and the inclusion of researchers from industry in lectures
Our central goal is to prepare our students to meet today’s challenges and find a successful career in future oriented branches of Biomedical Technologies.
In the first year, students can choose two out of three specialization modules, allowing them to tailor the program to their individual interests.
The second year of the Master’s program is flexible to allow students to gain practical experience in research institutes, industry or abroad.

Course Name: Double Master's Programme in European Studies
Target group:
The Master’s is based on the Bachelor’s degree course and consists of the three core subjects of inorganic, organic and physical chemistry and one of the following compulsory elective subjects: analytical chemistry, biochemistry, materials science, synthetic chemistry, medical chemistry or theoretical chemistry.
The combination of the three core subjects of inorganic, organic and physical chemistry with the optimal elective options in the compulsory elective subjects will open up excellent career prospects for Tübingen graduates. 
In chemistry, basic competencies are taught in various chemical and related disciplines. The course provides students with independent research in chemistry and forms the basis for a doctorate in chemistry.
• Special options within the scope of the course
• Close cooperation with the chemical industry in all areas of chemistry
• Modern chemical and physical-chemical laboratories for research and teaching
• Well-equipped departmental and institute libraries
• Several computer rooms for students with access to specific software
• Large-scale equipment centre for analytics (nuclear resonance spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, surface analysis)
• Workshops and glass blowing for apparatus engineering
The first chemical laboratory at the University of Tübingen was established in 1753 in the castle kitchen at Hohentübingen Castle. Numerous famous chemists have researched and taught at the University of Tübingen, including several Nobel laureates. Since 2009, the chemical institutes at the Morgenstelle have been housed in one of the most modern chemistry buildings in Europe.

Target group:
The core area of ​​Classical Archaeology is represented by the cultures of Greek and Roman antiquity.
The geographic framework includes Greece, Asia Minor and Italy, but also the areas of neighbouring cultures with which Greeks and Romans were in close contact. The time frame extends from the late Bronze Age (2nd millennium BC) to the late Antiquity (4th / 5th centuries AD).
The subject focuses on the material legacy of ancient cultures. These include artefacts such as architecture, sculpture, painting, ceramics and coins that can be experienced visually. As factors of historical situations, they have to be reconstructed in their utilisation context and their original function. The contexts include public and private life, politics, economics, sanctuaries/shrines and rituals as well as burials.
Classical Archaeology in Tübingen represents the entire scope of the subject in terms of research and teaching. In addition, the institute offers the specialisation Cultural Contacts and Cultural Transfer and – a rare opportunity in the German-speaking world – the option to combine classical archaeology with the study of ancient numismatics.
The institute's extensive collection of antiquities and coins also gives students the opportunity to work with original documents and to acquire their first museological experiences. The collection of plaster casts of ancient sculpture works is also intensively integrated into the teaching experience. It serves as visual training on important examples of Greek and Roman sculptures.
The continuous scientific processing of the collections, together with several field projects in the Mediterranean area organised annually in the summer months, guarantees a practical component.

Annotation: For more information on course contents and course organisation, see our course flyer:

Course Name: IBSA Dual Degree Master's Programme: Master of Business Administration – Six Business Specialisations
Target group:
The Master’s in Cognitive Science is an interdisciplinary course that provides in-depth and practical insights into different areas of our thinking and actions with subjects such as cognitive computer science, cognitive neuroscience, cognitive psychology, linguistics and philosophy.
Teaching concept and course contents
The aim of the Master’s programme is to consolidate various methodological and content-based aspects of cognitive science. The course prepares for professional practice in cognitive science and related (sub)disciplines and trains for interdisciplinary work as well as the effective exchange of knowledge and expertise across traditional subject boundaries. Through the option of individual specialisation and collaboration in cognitive science research within the framework of research internships, complex research methods can be learned and applied directly. The Master’s degree thus qualifies both for a postgraduate degree (doctorate) and an academic career as well as for interdisciplinary key positions in various professions.
This courses requires a clear interest in current research questions of cognitive science such as questions of perception, motor skills, learning, memory, problem solving, thinking and language as well as an interest in the application of cognitive science knowledge. Good English language skills as well as sufficient background knowledge in the core subjects of cognitive science in Tübingen are also important: Psychology and Computer Science.
The Cognitive Science course is interdisciplinary and combined with the disciplines of computer science, psychology, biology, linguistics, mathematics, medicine and philosophy. The Faculty of Mathematics and Natural Science, the three Max Planck Institutes for Biological Cybernetics, Developmental Biology and Intelligent Systems, the Centre for Neurology, the Hertie Institute for Clinical Brain Research, the Bernstein Centre for Brain Research and the Werner Reichardt Centre for Integrative Neurosciences offer opportunities to learn more about on-site research perspectives.
Area of study: Psychology / Neuropsychology

Annotation: For more information on course contents and course organisation, see our course flyer:

Focus: Middle East Studies, Democratisation and Regime Change, Development Policy, International Cooperation, Vergleichende Politikwissenschaft
Target group:
The M. A. in  Comparative & Middle East Politics and Society (CMEPS) is a two-year masters program jointly offered by the University of Tübingen and the American University in Cairo (AUC). It provides in-depth knowledge of the political and societal developments in the Middle East as well as analytical tools for under-standing this regions complex dynamics and challenges.
The focal point of the degree program is the relationship between societies and states in the MENA region as well as the dynamics of social and political transformation. Key topics are Comparative Politics of the Middle East, development politics and international cooperation, as well as issues of regime change and democratization. Students can choose from a range of elective modules, concentrating, for example, on International Political Economy, Peace and Conflict Resolution, or on issues in Middle Eastern culture and civil societies. Depending on their first degree, students of the CMEPS program will also take courses in either Political Science methods or basic Arabic (or German, respectively) during their first year. Irrespective of their first degree, by the end of their studies CMEPS students will have a unique profile which combines an advanced analytical knowledge of Comparative Politics with a strong specialisation in the politics, society, cultures, and language of the Arab Middle East.
To promote the link between theory and practice, study trips to international organisations and development agencies as well as to important political and cultural institutions of the respective host country are included in the program.

The degree course in Computer Science provides a very broad basis in all areas of computer science. At the same time, it offers a high degree of freedom of choice, as the classes can be individually customised and picked from the comprehensive range of courses offered by the Department of Computer Science. The application-oriented course allows students to either acquire knowledge in a non-computer science subject (e.g. physics, business studies, psychology, etc.) or to deepen their knowledge of computer science. In addition to lectures and seminars, the range of courses offered by the Department of Computer Science includes numerous internships and lectures by industry lecturers. Students can participate in a research group early on as part of a research project. In Computer Science, advanced Bachelor’s courses can be added, which simplifies a thematic reorientation of the Master’s in Computer Science and, especially, a transfer to the University of Tübingen.
Computer Science in Tübingen is one of the most research-intensive in Germany and is internationally known. It maintains close partnerships with major business enterprises and research institutes (e.g. three Max Planck Institutes in Tübingen) at the national and international levels. It is distinguished by the interdisciplinary cooperation with medicine, biology, psychology, media science and many other disciplines at the University of Tübingen.

Target group:
Data Science is a vibrant, interdisciplinary and rapidly growing field.
Data scientists must be able to acquire and understand complex and unstructured data, they must be able to interpret the meaning of the results, and they must be able to communicate the results to relevant stakeholders. Hence, Data Science requires a unique combination of (1) econometrics and statistics, (2) programming skills, and (3) domain knowledge.
This four-semester M.Sc. program reflects these requirements for a unique skill set, and students who enrol in this programme specialize in econometrics and they select from a broad set of modules on different aspects of business and economics. On top of that, they enrol in modules on data science techniques, which includes programming in R and python as well as the possibility to enrol in courses in Machine Learning in collaboration with the computer science department.
Areas of Specialization
    Econometrics
    Data Science Techniques
    Business and Economics

Course Name: International MBA - Focus Management in Emerging Economies
Target group:
The Master in Democracy and Governance in Europe prepares you optimally for a practical or academic career. You will learn to deal theoretically with all aspects of governance in the European multi-level system.
In terms of content, you are very familiar with the developments at the European level and in the Member States.
The main focus of the course is on the comparison of the EU Member States (Comparative Policy Research) in horizontal terms and the increasing vertical integration between the Member States and the institutions of the European Union (European Integration Research).
Central themes are the European multi-level system and normative questions of governance in Europe. This includes a critical analysis of European power and governance structures.
In Tübingen, we offer you comprehensive access to European research via political science. Democracy and governance in Europe are the main themes. You will examine the central normative questions of governance as well as the relationship between democracy and the economy. In contrast to interdisciplinary study programmes, which are often characterised by a juxtaposition of different disciplinary perspectives, interdisciplinary aspects are specifically integrated into the political science MA programme.
We thus provide you with an in-depth insight into the analytical concept of the multi-level system and the use of comparative methods to interlink the horizontal perspective and the vertical analysis of the interacting levels and to integrate them into a holistic view.
Area of study: Political Science / European Studies

_University Name: Technical University of Applied Sciences Wildau
Target group:
The M. Sc. in Economics is designed for students who have a general interest in Economics. You have a good Bachelors degree in Economics or any related field? You want to deepen your understanding of Economics without necessarily focusing on either International Economics or Finance? Then this is the program for you.
A broad range of field courses and electives gives you all the necessary flexibility to develop your individual academic profile. The courses available include International Economics, Game Theory and Industrial Organization, Innovation and Growth, Monetary Macroeconomics, Economic History, Microeconometrics, Theory and Empirical Analysis of Financial Markets and Financial Institutions. Graduates of this program will have acquired advanced, up-to-date knowledge in several areas of Economics and will be able to apply their knowledge in attractive professional careers, both in government institutions and in the private sector.
We place great emphasis on active student involvement. Attending a Master seminar, you will earn credits by writing a research paper on a topical issue of Economics, Econometrics or Finance, and by presenting your paper in class. Most importantly, you will write a Master thesis on a topic agreed upon between yourself and your thesis supervisor.
Working on your thesis under the dedicated supervision of a faculty member will allow you, with due effort, to move up to the frontier of academic research. In doing so, you will acquire methodological skills and expertise that greatly enhance your career perspectives, including a possible continuation of your education in an excellent Ph. D. program.
Double Degree Options
This program can be completed as a double degree with the University of Adelaide or the University of Nottingham.
Admission requirements: Earlier application deadline of 15 May.

Course Name: Master of Arts in Management of Technology Enhanced Learning
Target group:
The M. Sc. in Economics and Finance combines the strengths of our faculty in Econometrics and Finance. Just recently a crisis originating in the financial sector has proved to have severe consequences for economies and societies worldwide. It is therefore of the utmost importance that managers in the financial sector, regulatory offices and central banks have a sound understanding of the theory and real-world processes of financial markets as well as of financial instruments designed for risk sharing. Graduating from this program, you will be able to apply econometric methods to analyse financial data and to assess the validity of theoretical predictions and scientific forecasts for the financial sector. You will understand how prices of risky assets are (or should be) determined. And you will understand why financial instruments can increase social welfare, even though they may involve considerable risks for individual investors and society as a whole. In addition to field courses focusing on these issues, you may choose complementary elective courses according to your own preferences.
Graduating from this program is a first step towards an ambitious professional career in private and public institutions.
To allow for tailor-made personal curricula and research agendas, each program features specialization courses. You may choose to further your specialization in a certain field or to broaden your education by attending courses of a complementary nature, including interdisciplinary elements.
We place great emphasis on active student involvement. Attending a Master seminar, you will earn credits by writing a research paper on a topical issue of Economics, Econometrics or Finance, and by presenting your paper in class. Most importantly, you will write a Master thesis on a topic agreed upon between yourself and your thesis supervisor. Working on your thesis under the dedicated supervision of a faculty member will allow you, with due effort, to move up to the frontier of academic research. In doing so, you will acquire methodological skills and expertise that greatly enhance your career perspectives, including a possible continuation of your education in an excellent Ph. D. program.

Course Name: Master of Business Administration in International Business Consulting (IBC)
Target group: The Master's degree in Education and Learning: Culture  Politics  Society has two defining priorities: It enables students to work on a high academic level and qualifies them for challenging professional fields. The degree course centres on the conceptual and contextualised examination of education and learning. These are framed in various ways. They also owe their form to the transformation of the political field, cultural contexts and social structures and can only be investigated with recourse to advanced methods and ambitious theories. The curriculum is therefore characterised by traditional theories of education science as well as approaches that are explored in other disciplines. In this process, critical education theory meets post-structuralist concepts, gender research in education meets Postcolonial Studies, educational governance research meets concepts of philosophical aesthetics. This approach reflects the belief that education and learning processes can only be appropriately explored if not only the boundaries of the nation state but also those with neighbouring disciplines are overcome. Theoretical and empirical perspectives are then not in competition with each another but are mutually stimulating.
Admission requirements:
Deviating application deadline already on 15 June

Target group
The Master's degree programme in Empirical Cultural Studies (EKW) with its integrated profile lines Museum & Collections, Diversity, Cultural Analysis of Everyday Life offers a research and practice-oriented programme for students who wish to deepen their understanding of German and European everyday culture. 
Students acquire the ability to analyse everyday regional, ethnic, religious and gender-related phenomena and conflicts in the context of social, historical and socio-political developments.
At a high level, students learn to work systematically, theory-related and methodologically reflective, to research empirically and to present results in a comprehensible way. 
In three specialised profile lines (scope 30 ECTS), students can choose a perspective focus:
\tThe Museum & Collections profile line focuses on material culture, representation and memory. 
\tThe profile line Diversity examines the self-image of highly pluralised European societies with regard to their cultural, ethnic, religious, gender, age-related or physical differences 
\tThe profile line Cultural Analysis of Everyday Life focuses on the specifics of empirical cultural studies work along everyday life as an analytical category in a local and global perspective 
The EKW Master's degree programme combines intensive cultural-analytical training with practical orientation. Through a three-semester study project, it lays the foundation for a wide range of professional activities.
Area of study: Cultural Anthropology / Social Anthropology / Cultural Studies

Course Name: Master of Science in Green Electronics
Focus: Research methods as well as analysis and diagnosis of education processes
Target group:
Education is a crucial building block of our biography. It is crucial for our personal development, our professional career and how we participate in society. The aim of educational research is to provide the necessary knowledge base for policy and practice to enable every individual to receive a good education. It will explore questions such as:
•\tWhy do people learn differently?
•\tWhat part do aptitude and motivation play in learning success?
•\tHow can the German education system improve in international comparison? 
The Master's degree course in Empirical Educational Research and Educational Psychology (EBPP) is a strongly psychology-oriented degree course in which students learn to apply theories and methods of psychology to educational and educational science issues. The application of quantitative, empirical research methods (structural equation models, multilevel analysis, item response theory) plays a central role. In the Master EBPP, one specialises and uses these to get resilient answers to practically relevant educational questions.
Understanding education, helping to shape education:
In addition, existing studies such as PISA and TIMSS will be analysed: What are the main findings? How resilient and transferable are these to new framework conditions? In the Master EBPP, students also learn how the findings from educational research can be used to improve learning processes and educational systems. This includes diagnostics, the development of training measures and the evaluation of educational measures.
Electives allow students to tailor their studies to their individual interests and needs. In this way, it can be adapted to the respective previous knowledge and aligned with the field of employment in which one would like to work after graduation. Students may choose to focus on research or application, and may also complete an internship in the latter.
Possible careers:
Our graduates are sought after everywhere where teaching and learning play a role, e.g.
•\tin educational institutions
•\tin educational administration and policy (e.g. regional councils and ministries)
•\tin school development
•\tin professional/ private further education
•\tin foundations
•\tin the open economy
The degree course creates ideal conditions for a scientific career. Doctoral studies are possible within the framework of the LEAD Graduate School & Research Network. The course can be recognised for full membership of the Professional Association of German Psychologists (BDP).
Admission requirements:
Earlier application deadline already on 15 June.
•\tBachelor's degree in education, psychology, sociology, social science or a comparable degree course
•\tBachelor grade of 2.5 or better
•\tProof of at least 9 ECTS in Quantitative Methods/Statistics
•\tParticipation in the self-assessment for the Master EBPP ()
Area of study: Educational Research / Psychology

Course Name: Master of Science in Industrial Chemistry
Focus: Analysis of Educational Processes, Diagnostics of Educational Processes, Research Methods
Annotation:
Understanding education, helping to shape education:
Education is a crucial building block of our biography. It is crucial for our personal development, our professional career and how we participate in society. The aim of educational research is to provide the necessary knowledge base for policy and practice to enable every individual to receive a good education. It will explore questions such as:
•\tWhy do people learn differently?
•\tWhat part do aptitude and motivation play in learning success?
•\tHow can the German education system improve in international comparison?
In the Bachelor's degree course in Empirical Educational Research and Educational Psychology (EBPP), students learn how to investigate these and similar questions by collecting data and analysing it statistically in order to obtain the most robust and meaningful findings possible. They also learn to use these findings to improve educational processes.
For this purpose, the course combines psychology, educational science and related subjects with quantitative, empirical research methods (statistics). Students gain a comprehensive understanding of the individual, institutional and societal factors influencing and impacting educational processes. You will also acquire a sound basic knowledge of quantitative research methods and educational-psychological diagnostics.
Elective options within the degree course:
In three elective modules, students can each choose one of the following six areas of specialisation:
•\tEducation, digitalisation and media: How will digitalisation influence education?
•\tEducation and language: What influence does language have on learning and education?
•\tEducation and Society: What role does education play in society?
•\tEducation and Health: How can education promote health?
•\tEducation, Politics and Economics: What role does education play in politics and business?
•\tEducation and Learning: To what extent does education contribute to the development of young people?
Renowned professors and committed young academics accompany the students in their teaching. Regular lectures and seminars by international guest scholars complement the course offerings.
Possible careers:
Our graduates are in demand everywhere where teaching and learning play a role, for example
•\tin educational institutions,
•\tin education administration and education policy (e.g. regional councils, school boards and ministries),
•\tin school development,
•\tin professional and private further education,
•\tin foundations and
•\tin the free economy, for example in educational publishing houses.
The degree course also provides ideal preparation for a later career in science and the Master's degree of the same name at the University of Tübingen.
Admission requirements:
•\tAverage grade of the higher education entrance qualification
•\tOther criteria: Community or volunteer involvement, prior educational experience, extracurricular achievements such as successful participation in state or national competitions (credit given in the form of bonus points. The credit towards the higher education entrance qualification grade can be improved once by 0.3 points)
•\tThe instructional language in the degree course is German. Since much of the literature in Educational Psychology is written in English, the expected reading and source language is English at B2 level of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR). Individual events may also be held in English if necessary. Sufficient knowledge of English as a language of instruction at B2 level (CEFR) is therefore also expected.
Area of study: Educational Research / Psychology

Course Name: Master of Science in Integrated Circuit Design
Target group:
This program will enable students to achieve excellence in academic English, linguistic analysis, cultural studies, as well as the interpretation and evaluation of literary texts.
We pride ourselves on offering our students a wide variety of courses and programs ranging from Beowulf (the only complete Germanic epic) and Shakespeare to contemporary American and British novels, photography and film.
The program, commencing every semester, may be studied as a major or minor subject under the regulations of the GymPO II. It consists of five core aspects:
• Academic English
• Cultural Studies
• Didactics
• Linguistics
• Literary Studies
The teaching program is comprised of an academic and a didactics part.
The academic part focuses on the study of language and literature, the latter being designed to impart the methods and knowledge of literary and cultural analysis. The study of language is concerned with its history, its systems (grammatical, lexical) and language as a means of communication (Pragmatics, Syntax, Social and Psycholinguistics, Language Acquisition and Development).
To combine the academic knowledge with the demands of the classroom is the most important aspect of didactics. Students will be introduced to methods of teaching language and literature, empirical research in the field of education, and concepts for analysing and planning lessons in language and literature.

Course Name: Master of Science in Public Sector Innovation and eGovernance (PIONEER)
Target group:
The M. A. program English Linguistics provides a full understanding of current linguistics and a thorough training in the empirical methods used in linguistic research. The combination of empirical research with theoretical modelling is an internationally renowned hallmark of linguistics in Tübingen.
There is a long tradition of Linguistics in Tübingen, but there are more linguists now working on a wider variety of aspects of linguistics than ever before. In part, this is due to the exceptional success of Tübingen linguists in attracting research funding over the last 20 years. The course structure of the M. A. program English Linguistics reflects this depth and interdisciplinarity. While there is an emphasis on the description and processing of the English language, perspectives are always enriched by crosslinguistic comparison and interdisciplinary approaches ranging from experimentation to literary studies. For this reason, students can combine courses offered in English Linguistics with selected M. A. courses offered by the other Linguistics departments.
An important aspect of the M. A. program is the degree of choice in independent study. From the very beginning, students are encouraged to design and conduct their own research projects. Supervised by staff, they can contribute to the ongoing research of the Institute of English Languages and Literatures, and joint publications with staff are often the result. The academic and empirical skills thus acquired provide students with excellent qualifications for further study in Linguistics at doctoral level.
In recent international and national ratings, Linguistics in Tübingen fared very well. For example, in the QS World University Ranking, Linguistics is in the worlds top 100.
Admission requirements: Earlier application deadline of 31 May.
Area of study: English Studies / Linguistics

Course Name: Master of Science in Strategy and Organisation
Target group:
The Master’s in Ethnology/Social and Cultural Anthropology at the University of Tübingen teaches cross-cultural skills as well as extensive knowledge of South and Central Asia.
The programme includes regional-specific seminars, professional-practical courses, language lessons and tutorials to consolidate ethnological theories and concepts.
As part of a mobility semester, students have the opportunity to study in a country of South or Central Asia, carry out their own research or gain professional experience. The Department of Ethnology supports the stay through contacts with institutions in the regions, through cooperation agreements with universities, if necessary also through integration into research projects of the department.
The Department of Ethnology of the Asia-Orient Institute is based on internationally recognised teaching requirements and is associated with a number of international universities, e.g. in Azerbaijan, Georgia, India, Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan and Pakistan.
The areas of South and Central Asia are supplemented by research and lectures on Africa and the Near East.
Tübingen has an outstanding ethnological library, which mainly contains literature on the content and regional focus of the department.

Annotation: For more information on course contents and course organisation, see our course flyer:

Target group:
This double degree program is conducted in cooperation with the Università degli studi di Pavia. Students spend one year at the University of Tübingen and one year at the partner institution, earning a degree from both institutions. Students of this program are full students at both universities.
The Pavia Tübingen Dual Degree Program provides students with a unique study experience. Designed as a two-year program to be completed at both of the partnering universities, featuring a broad range of courses and granting two degrees, this master program perfectly prepares graduates for an international career.
This master program endows students with the skills and capacities necessary to succeed in the European economic world. With one study year in Pavia, Italy, and one study year in Tübingen, Germany, students experience two cultures, two campus lives, two academic practices. Graduates look forward to excellent career perspectives in various sectors.  By the end of their studies they are granted two master degrees: the Laurea Magistrale degree and the Master of Science degree.
Students may choose to either start their master at the Università degli Studi di Pavia or at the Eberhard Karls Universität Tübingen.  To complete their studies, students are obliged to obtain a total of 120 ECTS-Credits, 60 must be earned at each of the two universities.
The program may be completed on a PhD track, preparing students for an academic career.
Studying in Tübingen students focus on up to three specializations out of Economics, International Economics, Finance and Econometrics. Depending on their specialisation they take compulsory and elective courses.
Studying in Pavia students can choose courses out of a set of specialisations in the field of Economics.
A series of additional courses on economic globalization, like International Trade, Labor Migration, International Capital Flows and International Financial markets educate students to become true experts in International Economics.
Specialisations in Tübingen
        Econometrics (taught in English)
        Economics (taught in English)
        International Economics (taught in English)
        Finance (taught in English)
Specialisations in Pavia
        Industrial Organisation & Market Strategies (taught in English)
        International Economic Integration (taught in English)
        Finance (taught in English)
