Course Name: HighRR - High Resolution and High Rate Detectors in Nuclear and Particle Physics Research Training Group
Target group:
No other industrialised country has as few school psychologists as Germany. But they are urgently needed.  Berliner Zeitung (28.03.2012)
School psychology is an important field and application in psychology. The focus is on support for all those involved in school life: Pupils and their relatives, teachers, school leaders, school supervisors, school administration and legislative bodies. The task spectrum of school psychologists is very broad: 
• They support and advise, among other things, in connection with learning and performance problems (concentration, motivation, performance diagnostics, examinations), behavioural problems (school absenteeism, disruptive behaviour), conflicts and their constructive management (dealing with bullying, conflict moderation).
• They provide training and further education for guidance counsellors, teachers, school leaders and pupils (conversations, conflict management, social learning, health) and support in the management and prevention of school crisis situations.
• For teachers and school leaders, they offer supervision and coaching in individual and group settings, thereby contributing to the further development of their professionalism.
• In the case of questions concerning school development, they support teaching staff with their methodological competence.
• They explore how school works best and collaborate on improving the school system.
In addition to broad knowledge and skills in the psychological fundamentals, school psychologists should have specialised knowledge, especially in pedagogical psychology (teaching and learning), psychodiagnostics, psychological interventions (counselling, training, coaching), crisis intervention and conflict management, evaluation methods and quality assurance as well as clinical child and youth psychology. In addition, they should have a sound understanding of the school system and empirical education research. 
These contents are taught in the Master’s degree course ‘School Psychology’. It is the first, and so far the only, Master’s programme in school psychology for psychologists in Germany.
Area of study: School Pedagogy / Psychology

_University Name: LMU - Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich
Course Name: i-Target: Immunotargeting of Cancer (Internationales Doktorandenkolleg - Elitenetzwerk Bayern)
Target group:
School Research and School Development,
and what it means at the University of Tübingen: responsible school design, research-based reflection on teaching, developing skills for innovation.
What are the objectives and characteristics of this course?
The Master’s in School Research and School Development has been designed with two objectives in mind: On the one hand, the aim is to provide students with knowledge and skills for their professional activities and to contribute to their professionalisation. On the other hand, it is an important goal to stimulate innovation in schools and to create the foundations for sound reforms.
The course is a response to increased social demands on the education system and its stakeholders, as well as to the assigned and presumed self-responsibility of schools. However, the course also attempts to answer the question of how to deal competently with the growing heterogeneity of the pupils.
The course title School Research and School Development reveals the dual orientation of the course of study in a further way: research and development are combined and refer to each other. The aim of research and development activities is to achieve high-quality schools and teaching.
The programme benefits from the possibilities of a differentiated educational science institute, as exists in Tübingen: joint seminars with students of Social Education/Social Work, an exchange programme with Lehigh University (USA) as well as lectures from all departments are available to you.
Annotation: Can be studied either as a full-time or part-time (50%) course.
Admission requirements: Earlier application deadline on 15 June
Area of study: Educational Research / School Pedagogy / Educational Sciences

Target group:
Sinology in Tübingen uniquely combines competences to research and teach about China’s role in the emerging world society of the modern era (16th to 19th centuries) as well as modern and contemporary China, including Taiwan. This is done with philological, cultural and sociological methods.
The aim of the four-semester course is the development of academically sound expertise in China at the height of time.
The characteristic feature of the Tübingen Master’s degree in Sinology/Chinese Studies is the three-pronged combination of solid consolidation of language skills, a wide range of content-related teaching events and the attractive opportunity to study a semester abroad, with full of credits, at one of the renowned partner universities of Tübingen in Chinese-speaking countries.
Unique features
- European Centre for Chinese Studies at Peking University (ECCS)
- European Research Centre on Contemporary Taiwan (ERCCT)
- DFG Research Group Monies, Markets, and Finance in China and East Asia, 1600   1900 
- Trade Journal East Asian Science, Technology, and Medicine (EASTM)

Focus: Slavic Literature and Civilisation Studies, Slavic Linguistics, German-Polish Transcultural Studies
Target group:
The MA course in Slavic Studies can be studied with one of the following three specialisations: 
- Slavic Linguistics
- Slavic Literature and Civilisation Studies
- German-Polish Transcultural Studies
In the linguistic or literature specialisation, you learn, or consolidate your skills in, at least two Slavic languages. Your primary language is Russian, Polish or Czech. In addition to these, you can choose the secondary language from Bosnian / Croatian / Serbian and Slovenian. If you choose the specialisation German-Polish Transcultural Studies, you do not need a secondary language\; however, you will study Polish more intensively, with a compulsory semester in Warsaw.
If you choose the specialisation Slavic Literature and Civilisation Studies, you will be taking specialisation modules consisting of an advanced seminar and a lecture focusing on a selected literary or cultural theory, an epoch, an author or a genre.
In the specialisation Slavic Linguistics, you will examine, among other things, a section of grammar, a topic of pragmatics and text linguistics and a diachronic phenomenon. In addition to this, there will be further modules in both specialisations on different topics as well as a free module, which can be chosen from other disciplines (e.g. International Literatures, General Linguistics, History, Media Studies or Political Science).
The specialisation German-Polish Transcultural Studies comprises courses on linguistics, Polish literature and cultural studies, cross-cultural communication, translation studies and practice as well as literary criticism, with the courses of the third semester being taken during the compulsory semester in Warsaw.

Target group:
The Master's degree in Sociology with a focus on empirical social research at the Institute for Sociology at the University of Tübingen offers excellent research-oriented further qualification in the subject of Sociology.
Research focuses are:
• Practical research skills through application-oriented teaching research projects
• Deepening of quantitative and qualitative methods of empirical social research in the course of the study
• Specialisation in content in the main research areas of the institute
Structure of the course
The core of the Master's program is the imparting of practical research skills as part of a three-semester teaching research project. As part of a team, you independently carry out an empirical study and in this way, learn to put your acquired specialist knowledge into practice. The following topics are dealt with in the application-oriented teaching research projects: Family policies and parenthood, flight and migration, subjective consequences of social inequality and more.
In addition to deepening quantitative and qualitative empirical research methods in small groups, this Master's program also offers specialisation options in the following areas:
Migration, Education and Life Course
Gender Body Knowledge
Social Inequality and Institutions
An interdisciplinary field of study complements the chosen areas of work and serves to reflect Sociology in the mirror of other subjects or scientific cultures.
 You complete your studies with the Master thesis, in which you work on a self-chosen topic of Empirical or Theoretical Sociology according to scientific methods. In the sense of an international orientation of the course, English-language courses are offered every semester, and we support students in planning a study stay abroad (preferably in the fourth semester).
Admission requirements: Earlier application deadline on 15 June

Target group:
In four semesters, the Master’s in Sports Management prepares for sport-related occupational fields at the interface of sport and business and that require management skills. The study programme consists of the main subject Sports Science and the supplementary area of Business Administration, which is offered by the Department of Economic Sciences.
The Master's degree course in Sports Management is divided into
    Philosophy of Science, Theories of Sport Science and Methodology (15 ECTS),
    Fundamentals of Sports Science (15 ECTS),
    Profile building within sports science (15 ECTS),
    Scientific project work (12 ECTS),
    Profile-specific scientific project work (15 ECTS),
    Business lectures (12 ECTS),
    Key qualifications (6 ECTS),
    Master thesis (30 ECTS). 
These course contents are taught in modules, which are described in detail in the examination and study regulations as well as in the module handbook.
In the Master specialisation of Sports Management, students acquire knowledge and skills in the fields of business administration and sports management, which qualify them for their professional careers. The students:
    acquire sound knowledge of Sports Science and experience in scientific work,
    deepen basic knowledge in the fields of Natural Sciences, Humanities and Social Sciences in Sports Science,
    focus on Sports Management topics in in-depth seminars,
    receive an introduction to business fundamentals and core topics.
In addition, the Master specialisation in Sports Management offers students further education opportunities by spending a semester abroad. For example, through the partnership with the Japanese Graduate School of Business of Rikkyo University.
Admission requirements: Earlier application deadline on 15 June

Course Name: Berlin Graduate School for Global and Transregional Studies
Focus: Digital Media, Marketing & Sales, Data Science & Big Data Analytics, Digital Management & Leadership, Digital Human Resource Management & Virtual Organisations
Annotation:
Our Master's degree programme in Digital Management and Leadership (MBA) teaches you everything that the economy 4.0 needs.
With cutting-edge topics and content, ranging from teamwork, collaboration and change processes to digital business and digital transformation and the demands on a manager in a digitised world, you stand for a high level of expertise and in-depth methodological knowledge.
Digitisation has initiated rapid social change. New business models are only one side of the coin here - just as important is the change in values to which companies must respond. The Master's programme Digital Management & Leadership combines both challenges - technical and human.
The Digital Management Master is the optimal preparation for the challenges of digitisation and the radical changes that are about to take place in our society and companies.

Course Name: Berlin Graduate School Muslim Cultures and Societies
Focus: Personnel Management, Marketing Management, Business language French, Business language Spanish
Annotation:
Knowing about the function of language and communication in business relations, the command of management techniques, cross-cultural skills and sound business administration expertise are becoming more and more important in determining a company's success. Graduates of this distance learning course have precisely these skills. They also speak excellent English and can function as translators. They will be able to analyse operational problems from communication-based perspectives and develop solutions. They combine their knowledge of economic sciences and linguistic and cultural sciences, adept at applying this combination very well to a wide range of tasks. 
Graduates will be particularly qualified for a variety of professional fields thanks to the course's interdisciplinary character. Here are just a few examples: Training, continuing education and professional development, corporate communications, cross-cultural mediation, human resources, marketing, public relations, translation and interpreting as well as quality, process and diversity management. As experts in business communications, graduates can be deployed flexibly in these and many other areas.
As part of the course, you will have to complete a work placement (9 weeks, at least 35 attendance days), or perform equivalent work. This will allow you to apply in practice the academic know-how acquired in the classroom.  By the way: as an AKAD student, you will be able to participate in a three-week study session in Sacramento: through the California Campus Program.
Within the framework of the AKAD-study model, you decide yourself - depending on learning type, level of knowledge or interest - whether you participate in the additional seminars of your course of study at the AKAD University in Stuttgart or not.
Admission requirements: Proof of school-leaving certificate giving right of entry to higher education, or entrance qualification for universities of applied sciences, is required at start of course. It is possible to study without a general higher education entrance qualification.
Area of study: Translation / International Business Administration

Course Name: Berlin School of Economics PhD Programme (BSE PhD Programme)
Admission requirements: The conclusion of an employment contract with a practice partner (company or institution) cooperating with the university must be proven.

A general higher education entrance qualification or the subject-restricted higher education entrance qualification appropriate to the selected course, as well as a study and training agreement with a company or social institution. If proof of aptitude is also provided, applicants with an entrance qualification for universities of applied science or a professional qualification compliant to the regulations governing access to higher education (BerufsHZVO) may also be admitted.

Focus: Bioprocess Control Technology, Biomaterials / Materials, Technical Microbiology / Organic Products, Process Analysis, Biochemistry, Bio-Process Engineering / Fermentation Technology, Genetic Engineering, Bioinformatics, Biostatistics, Cell Culture Technology
Annotation: Biotechnology is one of the key sectors of the 21st century with great growth potential and diverse professional development opportunities. The interdisciplinary graduates of the Bachelor's degree in Biotechnology can take on tasks such as the biotechnological production of pharmaceuticals, biofuels and food, support environmental biotechnological processes and work with biosensors and bio-instruments.
Admission requirements:
Entrance qualification for general OR subject-restricted higher education OR higher education at a university of applied sciences 
By the third subject-related semester, an 8-week pre-study internship is required. Vocational training in a profession related to the degree programme is recognised as equivalent to a pre-study internship.
Prospective students should have a strong interest in the natural sciences, especially biology and chemistry, and a high degree of enthusiasm for technical issues. The choice of a science profile in the baccalaureate level is recommended. Good previous knowledge of the English language facilitates the reception of textbooks and specialised publications. A positive attitude towards numbers and equations is essential for understanding, especially the engineering aspects of the course.

Course Name: Graduate College: The Economics of Innovative Change
Focus: Financial Management, Marketing, Personnel Management, Accounting/Controlling, Taxes, Business Informatics (IT/Data Processing), Economic Law
Annotation:
The graduates of the Business Administration course have very good job market opportunities due to the special scope of their professional qualifications.  Thanks to training at the Ernst Abbe University of Applied Sciences in Jena with the high degree of practical relevance, graduates are able to solve business issues and problems in all areas of business and public service.  The functional focus of the work of the graduates is particularly in marketing, finance and accounting, in auditing, in IT / organisation, in human resource management as well as in auditing and tax advice.
Thanks to the thematic flexibility of the course, graduates can also be deployed in numerous areas of work.  Business know-how is in demand in companies in the private sector, in manufacturing as well as in the public and social sectors.  With the Business Administration degree and the relevant economic know-how connected with it, advancement towards management positions can also be simplified.
Admission requirements: Entrance qualification for general OR subject-restricted higher education OR higher education at a university of applied sciences

Focus: Personnel Management, General Management, Organisational Management, Economic Law, Financial Management, Accounting and Tax Law, Business Information Management, Market-Oriented Company Management, Corporate Control, Business and Economy
Target group: The distance learning Master’s course “Business Administration” is aimed at graduates of engineering or non-commercial degree courses and other university graduates (including business school graduates) with at least one year of professional experience in companies or organisations after completing their initial university education and now hold or intend to hold a management position.
Annotation: In cooperation with JenALL e.V., the Ernst Abbe University of Applied Sciences Jena offers a master's degree course for engineers and other academics (including business economists) with one year of professional experience as an accredited (AQAS) continuing education course. In this Master's degree course, you will be taught management and decision-making skills to work towards a corresponding managerial position or to advance further in this position.
Admission requirements:
Admission to the course of study is subject to possession of a degree in a diploma or bachelor's course degree at a university , or a degree recognised as at least equivalent with at least 210 ECTS point,  as well as at least one year of professional practice in companies or organisations following completion of higher education. The primary professional experience is usually directed towards non-commercial, especially technical areas, but should also include initial experience in management tasks, e.g. project management. Proof of knowledge of the English language must also be provided (e.g. with a TOEFL test with 72 points). For foreign applicants, proof of sufficient knowledge of the German language is also required.
If the number of applicants exceeds the planned number of admissions, applicants will be admitted on the basis of the final grade of their initial university education.

Focus: Business Informatics, General Business Administration, Economics, Law, Marketing, Personnel Management, Taxation
Annotation:
Practical, scientific work and application-related research should provide the students with the necessary professional, methodological and social skills that enable them to act independently and autonomously. The globalisation of the economy is taken into account.  Graduates will be able to support the management of an organisation in the field of Business Informatics, as well as to take on managerial tasks themselves after having been trained accordingly, or to be self-employed or freelance. The course should be completed in a reasonable time with a reasonable level of expertise in the field of Business Informatics.
The course imparts skills in both business and information technology issues.  Graduates can therefore be deployed in many areas where combined know-how in business information technology is required.
Admission requirements: Entrance qualification for general OR subject-restricted higher education OR higher education at a university of applied sciences

Focus: Clinical Optometry, Biomedicine, Refractive surgery, Child and sports optometry, Inter-disciplinary optometry, Vision Training/Therapy, Special contact lenses, Light and Lighting, Project Management, Business Administration
Annotation:
The graduates of the part-time Master's programme "Clinical Optometry", have a complex area of application that represents an excellent interface between people, medicine and technology, both in practical optics / optometry and health services as well as in research and development. This enables them to recognise, analyse and adequately supply visual disorders on a scientific level.  This includes optical and optometric as well as biological and clinical-medical knowledge and techniques to investigate visual disorders and achieve the best possible vision.
With the postgraduate and part-time Master's degree “Clinical Optometry”, you tap into other professional fields of application beyond the traditional optics trade, such as: specialised optician shops / optometry practices / institutes, contact lens institutes, ophthalmological facilities (ophthalmic practices and eye clinics) or institutions for the rehabilitation of the visually impaired. You will be able to apply comprehensive optometric studies using knowledge and techniques for the visual system and its measurement in a practical and targeted manner.
The scientific training during your studies and the creation of a Master's thesis also enable you to work at a research institute.
By imparting skills in business administration and project management, management positions in specialist shops, branches and companies in optics / optometry and the optical industry, for example in marketing or in research and development, can be well filled.
With the "Master of Science" degree, you also acquire an internationally recognised degree and thus have the opportunity to work abroad. And if you would like to continue studying, there is the option of starting a doctorate based on this.
Admission requirements:
First Degree: Bachelor degree in the field of ophthalmic optics/optometry with 210 ECTS
Alternatively:
- Bachelor's degree in the field of ophthalmic optics/optometry with 180 ECTS and a further 30 ECTS which can be proven by the end of the Master's degree course, e.g. practical professional experience and competences, subject-specific further and continuing education, subject-specific work abroad, optometric casuistry, guest lectures, active participation in relevant professional associations) or
- Engineering Diploma (University of Applied Sciences) optometry (7 or 8 semesters) or
- completed master training as a master optician and corresponding further university education
A school leaving certificate giving right of entry to higher education (Abitur) or an entrance qualification for studies at universities of applied sciences is not required separately, because the master's degree can entitle to an admission to the degree course 
- Overall grade of first degree of at least 2.5
- at least 1 year of qualifying professional experience in applied optometry

Course Name: Graduate Programme in Labour Market Research of the Institute for Employment Research (IAB) and the School of Business and Economics
Focus: Coaching, Management, Steering, Personnel and Organisational Development, Conflict / Crisis Management, Personal Skills, Methodical Skills
Annotation: The career-integrated and fee-based advanced training course qualifies its graduates as a coach and for management positions. The conception of the Master provides for a double qualification of the participants.  On the one hand, the course includes coaching for people responsible for management and control tasks. At the same time, managers are empowered to be able to coach their employees. In both respects you receive a well-founded academic training as a coach, which is based on the guidelines of the relevant coaching associations and in particular gives you an academic degree (Master of Arts).
Admission requirements:
Degree with 210 ECTS credits. Applicants with a degree of 180 ECT credits can compensate for 30 ECTS credits by alternative means or, after consultation with the programme director, by taking required credits.
At least two years of professional experience
A letter that expresses the motivation for the Master’s (max. 3,000 characters)
Experience with job-related consulting (coaching, supervision, etc.) is desired, as well as own basic competences in the consulting and/or management area.

Focus: E-Business, E-Commerce, Web Controlling, Online Shop Management, Mobile Applications, Software Engineering, IT Management, Online Marketing, Business Computer Science, Cloud Technologies
Annotation:
The graduate of the e-commerce course is a generalist in the Internet economy who knows how to connect worlds.  Temporal, spatial, social and technical boundaries are increasingly taking a back seat for digital companies.  The skills imparted open up direct application opportunities in a wide range of areas of the Internet economy.
E-commerce graduates have in-depth knowledge, skills and methods to identify, understand, evaluate, design and apply digital value-added systems, digital economic and transformation processes and internet-based technologies.
Admission requirements:
Entrance qualification for general OR subject-restricted higher education OR higher education at a university of applied sciences 
By the third subject-related semester, an 8-week pre-study internship is required. Vocational training in a profession related to the degree programme is recognised as equivalent to a pre-study internship.
Area of study: Engineering and Management / Business Administration

Course Name: Graduate School of East Asian Studies (GEAS)
Annotation:
E-Commerce Master in Jena: Study the future of commerce:
Comes to Jena, the Technology hub for omni-commerce, digital companies and the internet industry.
With the study of the M. Sc. E-Commerce (Master of Science) at EAH Jena, you choose a course with excellent future prospects in an industry with enormous growth and many tasks and opportunities, for example in the areas of E-Commerce, Mobile Commerce, Social Commerce or Omni Commerce.
Admission requirements:
The degree in Business Administration at the Ernst Abbe University of Applied Sciences in Jena is a university degree and access is regulated by the ThürHG (Sections 60 to 63) from December 21, 2006. A prerequisite for admission to the course is a Bachelor's degree at a university or a university degree recognised as at least equivalent with at least 210 ECTS credits in one of the following courses: E-commerce, e-Business, Business Informatics, Trade Management, Business Administration with a specialised focus or related courses.
The overall grade of the degree should be 'gut' (good) or better. If a Bachelor's degree with less than 210 ECTS credits has been acquired, the possibility of an internship, a project work in the scientific or practical area or a special study plan for the acquisition of missing credit points can be used.
Admission to the Master's degree course is also subject to provision of proof of adequate command of English language generally by means of a TOEFL test or by completing a module of the Bachelor's degree course in English. The module in English can also be a foreign language module.
For foreign applicants, proof of sufficient knowledge of the German language is also required. If the number of applicants exceeds the planned number of admissions, a selection process will be carried out. The departmental council determines the procedural modalities.
Area of study: Trade and Industry / Economic Sciences, Economics

Admission requirements: Entrance qualification for general OR subject-restricted higher education OR higher education at a university of applied sciences

Focus: Automation, Embedded Systems, Mixed-Signal Design/Optoelectronics

Bachelor and/or Diplom graduates with a degree in:

- Computer Systems Engineering
- Communications and Media Engineering
- Industrial Electronics or Microelectronics
Annotation: The degree offers a balanced ratio of basic and specialist knowledge, which gives graduates access to many modern and demanding areas of research and development. The Master's degree is a good starting position in industry, in research institutions and for further qualification.
Admission requirements:
Admission requirements for the Master's degree in "Electrical Engineering / Information Technology '' are a degree in the Bachelor's degree course in" Electrical Engineering / Information Technology "or" Automation Technology / Information Technology International 'at the Ernst Abbe University of Applied Sciences in Jena, or an academic degree recognised as equivalent in an identical or subject-related field of study in another educational institution.
Either the overall grade of the degree must be at least "Good" or a successful professional activity in the field over several years must be demonstrated. Proof of a successful language proficiency test (DSH level 2 or 3, TestDaF level 4 or 5 or other equivalent language certificates) is mandatory for foreign applicants.

Annotation: The Master's degree course opens up the possibility for you, as a specialist and manager in the field of accounting, finance and taxation, to expand your professional competences. This makes the MBA continuing education degree course unique in Thuringia.
Admission requirements:
The advanced training course in Finance - Accounting - Taxes (MBA) is aimed at specialists and executives from industry and retail companies as well as service providers such as credit institutions and insurance companies, tax advice and auditing as well as at people in other companies and institutions, primarily in the field of accounting and financing taxation who strive for a managerial position and have already successfully completed initial academic training (Bachelor's or Master's degree, university, university or technical college degree).
A prerequisite for admission to the course is a degree in an Economics course at a university with at least 210 ECTS credits or an academic degree recognised as at least equivalent, as well as qualified practical work experience of generally not less than one year after completion of the university degree.
To start the course, proof of knowledge of the English language at level C 1 of the Common European Framework (CEF) must be provided by TOEFL, TOEIC, IELTS, Cambridge, LCCIEB, A-PIEL or a comparable achievement.  For applicants, proof of sufficient knowledge of the German language is also required, either by taking a German high school Diploma or by completing a German university degree or by presenting the certificate "TestDaF" with the minimum rating level 2 or by passing the "German language test for university entrance (DHS)" or other comparable certificates after individual case examination.
Area of study: Financial Management, Insurance / Accounting, Taxation, Controlling

Course Name: RTG 2300 Enrichment of European Beech Forests with Conifers
Focus: Entrepreneurship, Marketing, Human Resources, Accounting, Company Management, Taxation, Labour Law, Innovation, Finance
Annotation:
Due to the age structure of their founders and successors, medium-sized companies will be increasingly dependent on competent managers in the coming years. Due to the increasing complexity of economic processes, a sound education in the field of global and international business is required.
This will result in a disproportionate need for managers in medium-sized companies in the future. But that's not all - large companies are also divided into medium-sized companies via group structures that, as more or less independent business units, have a corresponding need for managers.
The knowledge and skills imparted enable you to take a management position in precisely these companies. In addition to a qualified in-depth economic training in theory and practice, you will be in the position to grasp complex relationships and respond appropriately. They will be empowered to take on the core responsibilities of business leaders.
Admission requirements: Admission to the course of study is subject to possession of a Bachelor's degree in the economic sciences gained at a higher education institution, or a degree from a recognised university, with at least 210 ECTS credits. The overall grade of the degree should be at least “good”. If a Bachelor's degree comprising less than 210 ECTS credits was gained, a special curriculum is available for acquisition of the lacking credit points. Admission to the Master's degree course is also subject to provision of proof of adequate command of English language generally by means of a TOEFL test or by completing a module of the Bachelor's degree course in English. The module in English can also be a foreign language module. For foreign applicants, proof of sufficient knowledge of the German language is also required. If the number of applicants exceeds the planned number of admissions, a selection process will be carried out. The departmental council determines the procedural modalities.

Focus: Personnel Management, Corporate Control, Health Economics, Tax and Contracts, Law, Ethics, EBM and Social Law, Health evaluation, Public Health Management, Hospital Management, Organisational Management
Target group: The programme Master of Business Administration Health Care Management of the Ernst-Abbe-Hochschule Jena is aimed at professionals and executives of health and social care facilities as well as at persons, especially those in the medical field, who are looking for an executive position in health and social care facilities and who have successfully completed a first university degree (Bachelor or Master degree, degree from a university, college or university of applied sciences). This programme, unique in Thuringia, aims to systematically provide participants with all the knowledge and skills needed to take on managerial positions in health and social services, particularly hospitals.
Annotation:
The knowledge and skills imparted within the framework of this continuing education Master's degree will enable you to pursue a management position in healthcare and social institutions, specially in hospitals.
The Health Care Management degree in Jena is aimed in particular at doctors or other employees in medical institutions. As a result, the MBA allows graduates to work towards management positions in middle and senior management of health care facilities. An alternative to this path could be the scientific career. With an MBA, a doctorate can be started at the university. A career in public service is also conceivable. Here, the degree enables entry into higher service.
Admission requirements:
Prerequisite for admission to the course of study is subject to possession of a degree in the area of health economics, particularly in the medical field, gained at a higher education institution, or a degree with at least 210 ECTS points recognised as equivalent or better, and at least one year of professional experience in companies or organisations following completion of university education. Proof of knowledge of the English language must also be provided (e.g. Abitur - general higher-education entrance qualification - or TOEFL test with 72 points). For foreign applicants, proof of sufficient knowledge of the German language is also required.
If the number of applicants exceeds the planned number of admissions, applicants will be admitted on the basis of the final grade of their initial university education.

Course Name: iGRAD-Plant: Network, Exchange, and Training Programme to Understand Plant Resource Allocation (NEXTplant)

Annotation: Do you already have a first academic degree in industrial engineering or engineering and would like to gain further qualifications alongside your professional activities in order to be able to take on management and complex coordination tasks? Then the part-time and practice-oriented Master's degree course in Industrial Engineering and Management at the Ernst Abbe University of Applied Sciences Jena offers the ideal conditions for you.
Admission requirements: A prerequisite for admission to the course is a successfully completed Industrial Engineering or Engineering degree with a Bachelor, Master or Diploma with 210 ECTS points. In addition, at least one year of professional experience must be demonstrated. Engineers must also demonstrate additional Business knowledge in the form of courses, professional practice, etc. If necessary, these can be made up in the form of a special study plan. In the case of a first professional qualification with only 180 ECTS, an additional 2 years of relevant professional practice must be demonstrated after obtaining the degree. Applicants with a final grade of 2.5 or better will be admitted directly. Otherwise, an aptitude test is carried out by a commission, which is conditional on successful completion of a degree in Industrial Engineering or Engineering with a Bachelor, Master or Diplom degree with 210 ECTS points. In addition, at least one year of professional experience must be demonstrated. Engineers must also demonstrate additional Business knowledge in the form of courses, professional practice, etc. If necessary, these can be made up in the form of a special study plan. In the case of a first professional qualification with only 180 ECTS, an additional 2 years of relevant professional practice must be demonstrated after obtaining the degree. Applicants with a final grade of 2.5 or better will be admitted directly. Otherwise, a suitability test is carried out by a commission.

Focus: Production, Development, Technical Sales and Marketing, Product Management, Innovation, Modern Materials, Project Management, International Business
Annotation: You already have a first academic degree and would like to further qualify yourself in the field of industrial engineering in order to be able to successfully take on management, planning and coordination tasks? Then the practice-oriented Master's degree of the same name at the Ernst Abbe University of Applied Sciences is exactly the right offer for you.
Admission requirements:
- an overall grade better than 2.5 in a course qualifying for the Master’s course
- Bachelor's degree (210 ECTS points) in a course in Industrial Engineering
- A recognised academic degree in Industrial Engineering
- A degree in a Bachelor's degree in Industrial Engineering with 180 ECTS or Engineering if the preliminary work specified by the examination board of the department has been achieved
- Admission to the Master’s degree course in Industrial Engineering requires a positive result in the aptitude assessment procedure conducted by the Faculty of Industrial Engineering at the University of Applied Sciences of Jena (EAH Jena). Further information can be found in the department's aptitude procedure regulations.

Then secure your place on the practice-oriented Bachelor's degree in Industrial Engineering and Management (Digital Economy) at the Ernst Abbe University of Applied Sciences Jena and qualify yourself in an interdisciplinary subject area with excellent prospects!

Entrance qualification for general OR subject-restricted higher education OR higher education at a university of applied sciences

Annotation:
You love variety and are interested in economic and technical topics at the same time? You would like to learn things not only in theory, but try them out yourself? Then opt for the Industrial Engineering and Management degree. Here you are given an understanding of two worlds at the same time. Engineering knowledge is just as important as economic thinking in order to be able to analyse problems holistically from different perspectives. This "switching" is what makes the course so varied.
This interdisciplinary education enables you as an industrial engineer to increase the efficiency, reliability and flexibility of processes, to accelerate decision-making processes and to quickly understand complex issues. In companies, you are a link between departments and can develop new approaches and ways of thinking for the successful handling of problems through your overlapping specialised knowledge.
During the internship semester, you can apply the skills you have learned, make contact with companies and try out which job you are interested in.
Admission requirements:
Entrance qualification for general OR subject-restricted higher education OR higher education at a university of applied sciences 
By the third subject-related semester, an 8-week pre-study internship is required. Vocational training in a profession related to the degree programme is recognised as equivalent to a pre-study internship.

Annotation:
You want to travel the world, get to know new cultures and are interested in economic and technical topics at the same time? Then the Business Informatics International degree is the right choice for you.
Globalisation has become an integral part of the world economy. In companies, it is now part of everyday life to operate across national borders, because the world is becoming increasingly networked. In order to be able to contribute here, broadly diversified competences and experience abroad are essential.
In the WI International degree course, you will not only learn to think outside the box and be one step ahead of the events of a constantly changing world, but you will also have the opportunity to acquire international skills, get to know other cultures and at the same time acquire deep economic and technical knowledge.
In contrast to business informatics industry, modules are held in English from the 4th semester onwards. You will also complete a study semester and an internship semester abroad during a year abroad.
Admission requirements:
Entrance qualification for general OR subject-restricted higher education OR higher education at a university of applied sciences
By the third subject-related semester, an 8-week pre-study internship is required. Vocational training in a profession related to the degree programme is recognised as equivalent to a pre-study internship.

Course Name: International PhD Programme for Agricultural Economics, Bioeconomy and Rural Development (IPPAE)
Focus: Materials Testing, Materials Engineering, CONSTRUCTION, Plastics Processing, Metals, Manufacturing Engineering, Thermodynamics, Quality Management, Glass/Ceramics, Metrology
Annotation:
Do you have your smartphone at hand right now? Yes? Then try to imagine what remains of this smartphone if you first think away the display glass, then the plastic housing, the copper conductors, the silicon microprocessor and step by step all the other components made of materials. There's nothing left!
And this is true for all the products we need for our daily lives. Materials are everywhere. And even if they are often overlooked at first, 70% of all product innovations can be traced back to material developments. This applies to communications technology as well as to medical and energy technology, mechanical engineering and mobility technologies.
Would you like to learn more about these materials and their technologies and use this knowledge later to produce, improve or optimally use materials? Then the practice-oriented bachelor's degree in materials engineering offers you an excellent opportunity to study.
Admission requirements: Entrance qualification for general OR subject-restricted higher education OR higher education at a university of applied sciences

Course Name: International PhD Programme for Agricultural Economics, Bioeconomy and Rural Development (IPPAE)

Admission requirements: Admission requirements for the Master's degree course in Materials Technology / Materials Engineering is a good Diploma or Bachelor's degree in Materials Technology, Materials Science or a comparable scientific and technical degree course.

Focus: Biophysics, Ionising Radiation, Principles of Medical Electronics, Principles of Measurement Technology, Biomedical Technical Methods in Therapy, Biomedical Technical Methods in Diagnostics, Medical Devices Law, Signal and Systems Analysis, Principles of Control Technology, Analogue Circuit Engineering
Annotation: Due to increasing life expectancy, growing health awareness and technical innovations, medical technology is one of the key technologies in Germany. As an application of engineering in the field of medicine, it has become indispensable in many medical fields: For example, it plays a role in diagnosis in the derivation of biosignals (e.g. ECG), in imaging procedures (e.g. X-ray or ultrasound examinations) and in the determination of lung parameters or blood tests. It is also used in therapy, for example, for pacemakers, artificial kidneys and ventilators. In the digital age, the processing of patient data as well as signal analysis and image processing using various software is essential. Medical technicians are involved in the development, operation and maintenance of a wide variety of devices and systems.
Admission requirements:
Entrance qualification for general OR subject-restricted higher education OR higher education at a university of applied sciences 
By the third subject-related semester, an 8-week pre-study internship is required. Vocational training in a profession related to the degree programme is recognised as equivalent to a pre-study internship.
Prospective students should have a strong interest in scientific subjects, especially biology and physics, as well as a high degree of enthusiasm for technical issues. The choice of a science profile in the baccalaureate level is recommended. A positive attitude towards numbers and equations is essential for understanding, especially the engineering aspects of the course.

Annotation:
The EAH Jena's Master's degree course in Medical Technology imparts specialised knowledge of modern medical electronic device and system development. The focus is on medical technology research and applications with emphasis on selected areas such as medical metrology, diagnostic sensor technology and imaging. Within the scope of the Master's degree, you will be able to apply and develop various devices and processes.
In order to prepare you at an early stage for the requirements of modern technology-oriented companies and research institutions, the research orientation of the course includes a project work phase extending over three semesters. During this time, they work on their own projects in cooperation with companies and other scientific institutions. You can also gain an insight into the everyday working life of various institutions such as the University Hospital as part of some of the courses.
Admission requirements:
Bachelor's or Diploma degree particularly in the field of Medical Engineering or Biomedical Engineering Additionally, successful admission requires a positive result in the internal selection process, in which the following aspects are taken into account:
- The overall grade of the Bachelor's or Diploma degree (max. 75)
- Publications, posters or scientific lectures (up to ten points)
- Content and persuasiveness of the letter of motivation (up to five points)
- Professional training and experience in the field of Biomedical Engineering (up to ten points)
- Additional subject-specific qualifications in the field of Biomedical Engineering (up to ten points)
- Recommendations of the academic reviewers (up to ten points)
To pass the test the applicant must achieve at least 60 out of a maximum of 120 points.

_University Name: LMU - Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich
Focus: Pharmacology, Bioprocess Engineering, Bioprocess Controlling, Gene Technology, Molecular Cell Biology, Enzyme Technology, Bioinformatics, Biophysics, Bioinstruments
Target group:
Bachelor and/or Diplom graduates with a degree in:
- Biotechnology
- Medical/Pharmaceutical 
Biotechnology
- Bio-processing technology
- Pharmaceutical Chemistry
- or in an equivalent discipline.
Annotation:
Pharmaceutical biotechnology involves the use of biotechnological methods and processes in the context of medical applications. According to the colour of the blood, this branch of biotechnology is also called red biotechnology. The subject of pharmaceutical biotechnology is the use of the catalytic properties of biomolecules, cells and organisms, often optimised by genetic engineering methods, for the manufacture of pharmaceutical products and the development of diagnostic procedures.
Based on the molecular and cellular mechanisms of the regulation of metabolic processes and their pathological changes in the development of diseases, therapeutically effective substances are sought and biotechnological processes for their production are developed. Pharmaceutical biotechnologists also play a key role in the development and biotechnological production of diagnostics and vaccines. They are also qualified to make a relevant contribution in the development of microarray techniques, biosensors, analytical techniques and diagnostic devices.
Admission requirements:
The formal admission requirements are regulated by the degree course regulations of the Master's degree course in Pharmaceutical Biotechnology (see aptitude procedure regulations in the appendix of the study regulations).
Significant prerequisites for starting the degree are:
- a degree in a Bachelor's or Diploma course, in particular in the fields of biotechnology, bioprocess engineering, medical biotechnology, pharmaceutical biotechnology, pharmaceutical chemistry, pharmaceutical engineering, pharmaceutical and chemical engineering or biopharmaceutical technology
- Knowledge of the fundamentals of science and engineering, such as mathematics, physics, computer science, electronics, biology and chemistry
- Knowledge of biochemistry, process analytics, genetic engineering, microbiology, cell biology, bioprocess engineering and bioprocess MSR technology
Prospective students should ideally have a bachelor's degree in biotechnology and a strong interest in solving interdisciplinary problems. An enthusiasm for all stages of the pharma-biotech value chain - from molecular target to marketable pharma product - is expected.
In addition, admission depends upon a positive result in an in-house selection procedure. The following characteristics are taken into account.
- The overall grade of the Bachelor's degree or Diploma (max. 65 points)
- Publications, posters or scientific lectures (up to 10 credit points)
- Content and persuasiveness of the letter of motivation (up to 5 points)
- Professional training and experience in the field of Biomedical Engineering (up to 10 credit points)
- Additional subject-specific qualifications in the field of Biomedical Engineering (up to 10 credit points)
- Recommendation of academic reviewers (up to 10 credit points)
For admission, the applicant must achieve at least 60 out of a maximum of 110 points.

Focus: Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Development / Construction, Microsystems Engineering, Manufacturing Engineering, Computer Science, Measurement Engineering, CONSTRUCTION, Optics, Electronics, Materials Engineering
Annotation:
You like technology, want to develop and build - not just calculate. You think cars are okay but you find robots much cooler. You'd rather explore the next planet than the next highway? Would you rather have a super microscope than a super car? Then you are interested in High Tech Engineering. So are we!
In the bachelor's degree "Precision Engineering" we make you fit for a career in modern engineering. You'll discover a world of high-precision machines and computer simulations with laser manufacturing and 3D printing. We'll throw in some optics, computer science and electronics and you'll be building the next Mars robot!

Focus: Physical Materials Diagnostics, Introduction to FEM, Microsystems Engineering, Electronic Hardware Systems, Solid State Physics, Design and Precision Devices

Annotation:
The English-language Master's degree offers you the opportunity to gain further qualifications in scientific instrument engineering, following a first academic degree in the natural sciences or engineering.
Application deadline: 01.06. (1st deadline for applications from abroad) by 15.07.
Admission requirements:
Admission to the Master's degree course requires a qualifying degree with a good degree in a natural science or engineering subject where the curriculum covers the subject-related entry requirements (e.g. physical engineering, precision engineering, physics, electrical engineering, electronics, mechatronics, medical engineering) as well as a good knowledge of English. Admission is decided in an entrance examination. Graduates of bachelor's degree course other than Physical Engineering or Precision Engineering need extensive prior knowledge of Engineering Design, Materials Science, and Instrumentation. If this previous knowledge is not fully available, the selection committee will require the successful completion of all postgraduate basic modules (Solid State Physics, Microsystems Engineering, Design of Precision Devices and Introduction to FEM).
The entry requirement for the Master’s degree programme is a university degree with competent final degree grades in physics, science or a scientific engineering discipline whose curriculum covers the subject entry requirements (e.g. physics, physics engineering, microtechnology,precision engineering, mechanical engineering, mechatronics, electrical engineering, electronics ). English proficiency is also mandatory. The postgradual basis modules in semester one are assigned to the students depending on their Bachelor course to bring all the students with their different background to a comparable level.

Target group: The study programme is aimed at people who ideally have a first university degree and at least three years of professional experience. In addition, very good command of English is required. Applicants should be able to convincingly present their initial experiences of management.
Admission requirements: First professionally qualifying degree, at least three years of professional experience, proof of command of English (TOEFL or comparable test, GMAT/GRE).

Course Name: Spemann Graduate School of Biology and Medicine (SGBM)
Focus: Innovation and Technology Management, Business Analytics, Entrepreneurship, Global and Digital Strategy, Finance, Global Management, Soft skill workshop and language
Target group: The Master's degree course in Management at ESMT combines practical work in companies with first-class teaching and research material on current Business Management theories. As for the quantitative specialisations (Business Analytics\; Finance and Investments), the students should have a first degree in analytical fields (e.g. natural sciences, engineering, mathematics) or have very good quantitative skills (these can be documented by means of the GMAT test). All subject groups are admitted to the specialisations 'Entrepreneurship and Innovation' and 'Global and Digital Strategy'. In addition, very good command of English is required. The professional experience should be no more than 18 months.
Annotation:
All students learn a globally relevant language, such as Spanish or Chinese, and complete a six-month work placement in a leading company or Berlin start-up, as well as a social project with a non-profit organisation. 
Subject-specific specialisation possible in:
- Business Analytics
- Finance and Investments
- Entrepreneurship and Innovation
- Global and Digital Strategy
Admission requirements: A first professionally qualifying university degree is required, as well as analytical skills for quantitative specialisations. A very good GMAT (or GRE) result as well as proof of command of English (TOEFL or a comparable test). No more than 18 months of professional experience.

Admission requirements: Erster berufsqualifizierender Hochschulabschluss, mindestens dreijährige Berufserfahrung, Nachweis englischer Sprachkenntnisse (TOEFL oder vergleichbarer Test). GMAT/GRE bzw. ESMT Admissions Test sind fakultativ, werden aber für Studenten mit einem nicht-quantitativ/nicht-betriebswirtschaftlichen Hintergrund dringend empfohlen und können vom Admissions Committee verlangt werden.

Annotation:
The course starts for the first time in winter HS 21/22 at EUF.
The above-mentioned course component is studied as part of the BA in Education Sciences. In the Educational Science degree course, you study two partial courses (subjects) and the compulsory partial course Training, Education and Society.
The BA course in Educational Science is a polyvalent degree course, i.e. with a successful graduation, students do not have to exclusively complete an advanced master's degree in teaching. Further information on the course of study can be found at: 
But if you want to study the B.A. Educational Sciences with the firm aim of subsequently studying for a Master's degree in teaching, you must choose a subject combination that allows you to be admitted to a Master's degree ()
Admission requirements:
Admission requirements for the B.A. Educational sciences is the general higher education entrance qualification (Abitur) or the subject-linked higher education entrance qualification 'Social Sciences'. 
The entrance qualification for universities of applied sciences does not entitle the holder to take up university studies in Schleswig-Holstein. For information on the professional qualifications that entitle you to study, visit .
 Additional qualifications are required for the following subjects: 
Performing Arts, Fine Arts, Music and Physical Education require a passed qualifying exam 
Since Performing Arts can be chosen for the first time at EUF for HS 21/22, there will first be an info workshop this year and no qualifying exam. Detailed information can be found on the admission page.
Danish, English. French and Spanish require sufficient language
skills Details can be found on the admissions page under the tab "Additional qualifications"
An up-to-date list of the subjects with and without admissions restrictions for the 1st semester can be found on the admissions page under the tab "Subjects".

Focus: Art Education, Art (Teaching Qualification)
Annotation:
In this M.Ed. Degree course, you will study a further subject in addition to the above-mentioned subject and the compulsory partial course Training, Education and Society.
The Master of Education (M.Ed.) degree opens up a variety of career paths for you. You can further qualify for teaching qualification (subsequent traineeship), enter the (non-school) job market directly or even do a doctorate.
Admission requirements:
Prerequisite for admission to the degree course for a teaching qualification for Primary Schools with the degree of Master of Education is 
a) proof of a qualified Bachelor's degree, 
b) a subject combination according to Art.5 of these examination and study regulations, 
c) at least 50 credit points in each of the school subjects as well as 35 credit points from educational science and other disciplines that deal with questions of education and upbringing (e.g. psychology, sociology, philosophy). 
d) proof of basic pedagogical and didactic qualifications in the areas of dealing with heterogeneity and inclusion as well as the basics of inclusive assessment, continuous language education and the teaching of media competence and) proof of successful completion of school internships of at least six weeks.

Annotation:
In this M.Ed. Degree course, you will study a further subject in addition to the above-mentioned subject and the compulsory partial course Training, Education and Society. The above mentioned degree course can be studied as Secondary-II-level - subject.
The Master of Education (M.Ed.) degree opens up a variety of career paths for you. You can further qualify for teaching qualification (subsequent traineeship), enter the (non-school) job market directly or even do a doctorate.
Admission requirements:
Prerequisite for admission to the Master of Education degree in Comprehensive Schools is 
a) proof of a qualified Bachelor's degree, 
b) a subject combination according to Art.5, 
c) at least 60 credit points in each of the school subjects as well as 35 credit points from educational science and other disciplines that deal with questions of education and upbringing (e.g. psychology, sociology, philosophy), and 
d) proof of basic pedagogical and didactical qualifications in the areas of dealing with heterogeneity and inclusion as well as the basics of inclusive assessment, continuous language education and the teaching of media competence and 
e) proof of successful completion of school internships of at least six weeks.

Annotation:
In this M.Ed. Degree course, you will study the special education subjects chosen in the Bachelor's degree in addition to the above-mentioned subject, and the special educational psychology sub-programme is compulsory.
Art is elective for both primary and secondary education majors.
The Master of Education (M.Ed.) degree opens up a variety of career paths for you. You can further qualify for teaching qualification (subsequent traineeship), enter the (non-school) job market directly or even do a doctorate.
Admission requirements:
Applicants for the Master of Special Education must state in the online application whether they choose the primary or secondary level.
The prerequisite for admission to the degree course teaching qualification for the degree of Master of Education in Special Needs Education is 
a) proof of a qualified Bachelor's degree with a partial degree course in Special Needs Education, including two of the subject areas named in Art. 5 Para. 1, with a teaching subject according to Art. 5 Para. 4 and with a professionalisation area "Educational Sciences", 
b) in Special Needs Education, proof of at least 50 credit points, within which at least 15 credit points each in the two targeted subject areas must be proven, 
c) in a teaching subject from the focus on primary level, proof of at least 50 credit points or 
d) in a teaching subject from the focus on secondary level, proof of at least 60 credit points as well as e) from the professionalisation area "Educational Sciences" with school-relevant contents (e.g. educational science and pedagogy).
e) proof of at least 35 credit points from the professionalisation area "educational sciences" with school-relevant contents (e.g. educational science and educational psychology, sociology or philosophy) and 
f) proof of successful completion of school internships of at least six weeks.
Area of study: Special Pedagogy, inclusive Pedagogy (Teaching Degree) / Art (Teaching Degree)

Focus: Art Education, Art (Teaching Qualification)
Annotation:
In this M.Ed. Degree course, you will study a further subject in addition to the above-mentioned subject and the compulsory partial course Training, Education and Society.
The Master of Education (M.Ed.) degree opens up a variety of career paths for you. You can further qualify for teaching qualification (subsequent traineeship), enter the (non-school) job market directly or even do a doctorate.
Admission requirements:
Prerequisite for access to the Master's degree for teaching at secondary schools (grammar school teaching) is
a) proof of a qualified Bachelor's degree,
b) a combination of subjects in the Bachelor that entitles the student to study,
c) in the school subjects at least 60 credit points each and 35 credit points from the professionalisation area 'Educational Sciences' with school-relevant content (e.g. Educational Science and Educational Psychology, Sociology or Philosophy) and
d) proof of successful completion of school internships of at least six weeks.
Graduates of a Bachelor's degree course according to No. a) who have not acquired 60 or 35 credit points according to No. c) can be granted admission on the condition that the remaining credit points are earned during the Master’s degree. This admission is usually only granted if the standard period of study is not exceeded despite the additional credit points to be earned, which means that no more than 15 CP are missing.

Annotation:
In addition to the above-mentioned general education subject for the Master Vocational Education - Teacher Training at Vocational Schools (M.Ed.) with the specialisation in Nutrition and Home Economics, the sub-courses Vocational Education and Vocational Specialisation in Nutrition and Home Economics must be studied.
The Master of Education (M.Ed.) degree opens up a variety of career paths for you. You can further qualify for teaching qualification (subsequent traineeship), enter the (non-school) job market directly or even do a doctorate.
Admission requirements:
Prerequisite for admission to the degree course Master of Vocational Education for teaching qualification at vocational schools with the vocational specialisation of Nutrition and Home Economics with the degree Master of Education is 
a) proof of a qualified Bachelor's degree with a partial degree course corresponding to the vocational specialisation of Nutrition and Home Economics with a scope of at least 50 credit points, a general education subject studied in the Bachelor's degree according to the permissible partial courses of study specified in Art. 5 Para. 3 in the scope of at least 60 credit points as well as educational science/vocational pedagogy components of at least 50 credit points, of which at least 25 credit points are vocational pedagogy and 
b) proof of at least one year of professional activity in the vocational field of nutrition and home economics or of at least one year of practical training in the vocational field of nutrition and home economics or of completed vocational training. Proof of this must be submitted by the time of registration for the Master's thesis at the latest.
Area of study: Nutrition, Home Economics (Teaching Degree) / Art (Teaching Degree)

The Master of Education (M.Ed.) degree opens up a variety of career paths for you. You can further qualify for teaching qualification (subsequent traineeship), enter the (non-school) job market directly or even do a doctorate.
Admission requirements:
Prerequisite for admission to the degree course for a teaching qualification for Primary Schools with the degree of Master of Education is 
a) proof of a qualified Bachelor's degree, 
b) a subject combination according to Art.5 of these examination and study regulations, 
c) at least 50 credit points in each of the school subjects as well as 35 credit points from educational science and other disciplines that deal with questions of education and upbringing (e.g. psychology, sociology, philosophy). 
d) proof of basic pedagogical and didactic qualifications in the areas of dealing with heterogeneity and inclusion as well as the basics of inclusive assessment, continuous language education and the teaching of media competence and) proof of successful completion of school internships of at least six weeks.

Annotation:
In this M.Ed. Degree course, you will study the special education subjects chosen in the Bachelor's degree in addition to the above-mentioned subject, and the special educational psychology sub-programme is compulsory.
Catholic Religion is elective for both the primary and secondary education majors.
The Master of Education (M.Ed.) degree opens up a variety of career paths for you. You can further qualify for teaching qualification (subsequent traineeship), enter the (non-school) job market directly or even do a doctorate.
Admission requirements:
Applicants for the Master of Special Education must state in the online application whether they choose the primary or secondary level.
The prerequisite for admission to the degree course teaching qualification for the degree of Master of Education in Special Needs Education is 
a) proof of a qualified Bachelor's degree with a partial degree course in Special Needs Education, including two of the subject areas named in Art. 5 Para. 1, with a teaching subject according to Art. 5 Para. 4 and with a professionalisation area "Educational Sciences", 
b) in Special Needs Education, proof of at least 50 credit points, within which at least 15 credit points each in the two targeted subject areas must be proven, 
c) in a teaching subject from the focus on primary level, proof of at least 50 credit points or 
d) in a teaching subject from the focus on secondary level, proof of at least 60 credit points as well as e) from the professionalisation area "Educational Sciences" with school-relevant contents (e.g. educational science and pedagogy).
e) proof of at least 35 credit points from the professionalisation area "educational sciences" with school-relevant contents (e.g. educational science and educational psychology, sociology or philosophy) and 
f) proof of successful completion of school internships of at least six weeks.
Area of study: Special Pedagogy, inclusive Pedagogy (Teaching Degree) / Catholic Religion (Teaching Degree)

Course Name: English and American Studies / English Linguistics
Annotation:
The above-mentioned course component is studied as part of the BA in Education Sciences. In the Educational Science course, you study two partial courses (subjects) and compulsory the partial course Training, Education and Society.
The BA course in Educational Science is a polyvalent degree course, i.e. with a successful graduation, students do not have to exclusively complete an advanced master's degree in teaching. Further information on the course of study can be found at: 
But if you want to study the B.A. Educational Sciences with the firm aim of subsequently studying for a Master's degree in teaching, you must choose a subject combination that allows you to be admitted to a Master's degree ()
Admission requirements:
Admission requirements for the B.A. Educational sciences is the general higher education entrance qualification (Abitur) or the subject-linked higher education entrance qualification 'Social Sciences'. 
The entrance qualification for universities of applied sciences does not entitle the holder to take up university studies in Schleswig-Holstein. For information on the professional qualifications that entitle you to study, visit .
 Additional qualifications are required for the following subjects: 
Performing arts, fine arts, music, and physical education require a passing score in Danish, English. French and Spanish require sufficient language skills. Details can be found on the admissions page under the tab "Additional qualifications" A current list of the subjects with and without admissions restrictions for the 1st semester  can be found on the admission page under the tab "Subjects".

Focus: Intercultural perspectives, Interdisciplinary, German/English/Scandinavian Culture, Cultural Management, Cultural Studies
Target group: Bachelor's degree graduates in Linguistics, Cultural Studies and Humanities, with an interest in an interdisciplinary investigation of German-speaking, English-speaking and Scandinavian cultural spaces.
Annotation: Optionally, lecturers are offered in Danish.
Admission requirements:
Applicants for the Master of Arts / Kultur-Sprach-Medien can be admitted if they meet the following requirements:
1.) a first degree (e.g. Bachelor, Magister, Diplom, state exam) at a scientific university in Germany or abroad based on at least three years of study, in one of the following subjects is part of this degree: English / American studies (English), Scandinavian Studies (Danish), German studies (German), Romance studies (French, Spanish), Cultural Studies, Media Studies, Art or Textiles, as well as comparable courses that are available in at least one of the following courses in the Master’s degree course in Culture - Language - Media specialisation areas with at least 60 credit points achieved:  Literature, Linguistics, Cultural Studies, Media Studies, Art / Visual Culture
or
a degree in the Bachelor's degree course 'European Cultures and Societies' (EUCS) from the Europa-Universität Flensburg
or
a Bachelor's degree in Cultural and Language mediators within the framework of the German-Danish cooperation between the Syddansk Universitet and the Europa-Universität Flensburg
and
2.) Proof of sufficient knowledge of the English and German languages, whereby proof must be provided that one of the two languages is mastered at level C1, the other at B2 level.
Area of study: Intercultural Studies / Cultural Studies / Media Culture / General Literary Studies / Linguistics / Business Administration

_University Name: LMU - Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich
Annotation:
In this M.Ed. Degree course, you will study a further subject in addition to the above-mentioned subject and the compulsory partial course Training, Education and Society.
The Master of Education (M.Ed.) degree opens up a variety of career paths for you. You can further qualify for teaching qualification (subsequent traineeship), enter the (non-school) job market directly or even do a doctorate.
Admission requirements:
(1) Prerequisite for admission to the Master of Education degree course in Elementary School Teaching is 
a) proof of a qualified Bachelor's degree, 
b) a subject combination according to Art.5 of these Examination and Study Regulations,
c) at least 50 credit points in each of the school subjects as well as 35 credit points from Educational Science and other disciplines that deal with questions of education and upbringing (e.g. psychology, sociology, philosophy), d) proof of basic educational and didactic qualifications in the subject areas of dealing with heterogeneity and inclusion as well as the basics of inclusive assessment, continuous language acquisition, and the development of a new language. 
 and) proof of successful completion of school internships of at least six weeks. 
(2) If 50 credit points per subject were not acquired in the Bachelor's degree, the Admissions Office may grant conditional admission to acquire the missing credit points during the Master's degree.
(3) If no evidence of a qualified Bachelor's degree is provided at the time of application, admission may be granted subject to conditions. Proof of the qualified Bachelor's degree must be provided within the deadline set by the university and announced in the notification of admission. If the proof is not provided in due time, the admission is to be revoked and any enrolment that may already have taken place is to be cancelled.
Area of study: Danish (Teaching Degree) / Primary Education, Primary School Pedagogy

_University Name: LMU - Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich
Focus: Education in Childhood and Adolescence, Adult education, Intercultural Education, European Education Policy, Empirical Education Research
Annotation:
The focus of the degree course Education in Europe (M.A.) is the examination of extracurricular education in and through Europe.
You can choose between the focal points 'Education in childhood and adolescence' and 'Education in adulthood'. 
In addition to the research-based examination of extracurricular educational processes, an internship enables you to engage in an action-based examination and reflection of the conditions of pedagogical action in specific contexts. The elective subjects (European Studies, Sociology, Economics of Education, Philosophy of Education, Media Education, Counselling and Organisational Psychology) take into account the interdisciplinary and international orientation.
Admission requirements:
Applicants for the Master of Arts / Education in Europe can be admitted if they meet the following requirements:
1.) Successful completion of a Bachelor's degree in Educational Science from the Europa-Universität Flensburg with the specialisation option 'extracurricular educational science' or
2.) a completed equivalent, at least six semester university degree at a university or university of applied sciences in an accredited course.
Equivalence within the meaning of number 2 exists if at least 80 credit points (LP or ECTS points) are demonstrated in the field of Educational Science / Pedagogy.
If 80 credit points (CP or ECTS points) cannot be clearly demonstrated in the field of Educational Science / Pedagogy, the decision on whether external degrees are equivalent is made by the admissions committee.
Applicants who do not have a German-language university entrance qualification or have not obtained their German-language university degree must also provide proof of sufficient knowledge of the German language (TestDaF, DSH exam, each at level C1).
Area of study: Pedagogy, Educational Science / Intercultural Studies

However, if you want to continue on to the B.A. If you want to study a Master's degree in educational sciences for teaching qualification, you take the two subjects in the Bachelor's degree that you must then continue in the Master's degree (teaching profession).
